It is necessary to treat sovereign debt alongside all other obligations required by participation in a monetary area, and it is necessary
that the evolution of this work does not veer towards the dangerous idea of sanctions, and I count on Commissioner Barnier and his experience to help the Commission move in this direction.
A second note to sincerely congratulate you on the work accomplished in financial oversight.
I believe that Commissioner Barnier, in particular, together with this Parliament and the Belgian Presidency, have managed to reach a good agreement, an agreement that does us honor.
and which defends the interests of European citizens. And my hope is that the remaining agenda follows the same methodology and that we achieve the same success.

Thirdly, in particular, I would like to tell you that I sincerely hope that, with regard to resolving banking crises, especially those involving systemic and cross-border banks, progress will be made in emphasizing the European dimension.
Lastly, Mr. Commissioner, it is very important to revisit our agenda for the G20. In particular, if we do not want to abandon the fight against fraud and French tax evasion,
fiscal, if we do not want to give up the fight against tax havens and if we still want a more determined contribution from banks and financial services to work effectively.

Thank you, Madam President. Today, we are discussing yet another situation of human rights violation, that of the imprisonment of Syrian activist Aytan Almaleh, an 80-year-old lawyer, accused of allegedly spreading false, exaggerated news that weakens his country's national sentiments.

In addition to the violation of numerous treaties and international conventions, the imprisonment of this human rights defender is also contrary to the country's own legislation, which stipulates that military courts should not have jurisdiction over civilians.

The decision that was made regarding this man and regarding other Syrian prisoners detained for similar reasons, the various arrests, the restrictions on freedom of movement, and the arbitrary measures taken.
by the Syrian authorities are practices that contradict Syria's important role in the entire region and do not reflect the efforts that have been made in this country to improve the social situation.
I repeat, today we are discussing yet another situation of human rights violation.
It is not possible to isolate it from the various discussions we had here this week.
I highlight two. The first, the rejection of the death sentence by stoning imposed on Sakineh Ashtiani.
Many voices united and there have already been some results.

It is not yet time to sing victory, but even less so is it time for us to remain silent. Today, we approved a significant resolution against the abuses imposed by Sarkozy's government on Roman and Bulgarian citizens.
The defense of human rights knows no borders and is not a struggle to be waged solely beyond our shores.
Today we set a good example of how to halt it within our doors as well.
The unjustifiable imprisonment of Aitan Almaleh unites us all here today.
He is a human rights advocate.
Human rights defenders must be free individuals, and this is what we demand of the Syrian authorities.
We, too, as human rights defenders, will not leave you alone. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, the growing trend for the safety profile of new medicines to only be fully understood after their market entry necessitates a more effective pharmacovigilance system than has been in place hitherto.
We are faced with a typical risk management problem, but at a macro and supranational level. We have brought it closer to citizens. Now.
Over the past few decades, new medications have played a crucial role in public health and healthcare advancements.
Adverse reactions caused by medications continue to be, however, the fifth leading cause of hospital death.
The proposals presented strengthen the contribution of medicines to modern public health through a community pharmacovigilance system, enhancing coordination and transparency.
Its objective is the monitoring, early detection, communication, and evaluation of adverse reactions.
The new medications will have a graphic symbol indicating that they are still under scrutiny.
User participation in control is encouraged. National-level efficacy studies are promoted, raising awareness of environmental consequences and refining community control institutions. The Praco.
That is why, Mr. President, I welcome the proposals.
I congratulate the rapporteur, as well as the Commission, for their spirit of cooperation, and also the Spanish Presidency.
and, therefore, with the proposals presented in this legislative package, welcoming the final document to be voted on tomorrow. Thank you, Mr. President.
Mr. President, I would like to begin by expressing my gratitude and congratulations to the rapporteur, as well as to all the colleagues who were involved in this process.
We know that adverse drug effects are the fifth leading cause of hospital deaths, a fact that bears repeating, and a robust and transparent drug surveillance system is crucial.
We now have the opportunity to enhance the safety of medications that are already available, going beyond laboratory tests which do not always anticipate problems.

If concrete examples were needed to justify the importance of a new system, consider what happened with the H1N1 flu vaccine. There was haste in bringing the vaccine to market and negligence in investigating the side effects that were detected and which still delay a complete inquiry.
That is why it is necessary for us to continue deepening this path.
This Directive ensures the more active involvement of healthcare professionals and patients in identifying difficulties.
Indeed, cooperation between countries and the Union can be a positive-sum game.
A Europe lacking economic, social, and territorial cohesion is not a Union.
Mountainous regions, islands, and areas with low population density face particularly challenging obstacles that must be overcome in the name of a Europe of the peoples.
But we must go beyond declarations of intent, otherwise, we have the reverse effect, that is, we reinforce inequalities.
These regions are vast reservoirs of significant resources.
Biodiversity, forests, wetlands, and green areas provide an essential service for all, yet they face subsequent economic constraints.
There is a need to reciprocate.
The populations of these regions should be supported in solidarity by all.
I present two proposals.
First, the potential contribution to science and to development.
Many of these regions are authentic outdoor laboratories, given their wealth, but do not have equal access to resources for research.
Why not endow them with centers of excellence in research, creating high-quality jobs and boosting their economies?
A second proposal pertains to energy.
These regions can and should serve as embryos for projects that demonstrate the potential of energy self-sufficiency and sustainability, particularly through microgeneration from local sources.
Reducing dependency, increasing equality, and creating jobs.
Lastly, I wish to point out that using GDP as the sole or primary indicator for the allocation of aid funds can only lead to further injustice.
It is therefore very important to use supplementary data, particularly those that depict the social and economic reality of these regions.
I cannot fail to make special mention here of the peoples of the Azores, Madeira, the mountainous regions, and the depopulated interior areas of Portugal.
Through their efforts, they contribute greatly to the development and to the quality of life of all Europeans.
These and all regions have their own context.
Social, economic, and territorial cohesion should not be viewed as a charitable service.
This is where we define whether or not we want a true European redistribution policy.
I consider this resolution, for all these reasons, an important but first step.

For the celebration, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, the goal of territorial cohesion, now enshrined in the Treaty of Lisbon, embodies the value of European solidarity and the commitment of the Member States and the Union to reduce the existing disparities among the various regions.
It is not enough, however, to express the objectives to be achieved in the text of the treaties.
There are regions within the Union that face permanent constraints which significantly condition their economic and social development.

It is therefore necessary to implement specific programs that effectively and realistically overcome the delay in these regions, by promoting an adaptation of their development model to their potential and resources, and contributing to achieving the objectives of the EU 2020 strategy.
This incentive to these regions should result not only from the means of regional policy, through its structural adjustment instruments, such as the Cohesion Fund and the four structural funds, but
also from a different use of the various sectoral policies, which have a significant territorial impact in each region and can, therefore, have a dynamizing effect on their economies.
For the determination of European aid to these regions, it is certain that we should retain GDP as the main eligibility indicator.

However, and taking into account its natural disadvantages, it becomes relevant to resort to other measurable criteria, capable of providing a more realistic picture of its level of development, such as the unemployment rate, population density, or the level of education.
Only in this way will it be possible to have a more comprehensive portrait of the complex reality of the most disadvantaged regions.

Consider, for this purpose, the case of the outermost regions, which were recognized by the new treaty and which constitute a group of regions within the European Union that have specific characteristics and also deserve special treatment.
The ultra-peripheral regions, united due to their particular characteristics, also diverge in their levels of development.

Also with regard to these, supplementary GDP indicators should be employed, capable of providing a more comprehensive description of their specific reality and thus contributing to a more accurate determination of their level of development. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President. I support this motion for a resolution which calls for the need for a European strategy to make it possible to translate the principle of cohesion.
territorial gain from the Treaty of Lisbon in opportunities for the populations of territories suffering from various permanent natural constraints to participate in the European project.

I come from a region, the Azores, where these constraints converge and intensify, much like other regions designated as ultra-peripheral regions of Europe, as per Article 349 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.
Following the Commission's communication, the outermost regions joined forces for Europe in 2008 and after the broad debate in which the OUTR themselves participated.
Proactively, we also now await our version of this strategy, which will need to take into account not only our constraints but especially our potentialities.
I therefore appeal to the Commission to be clear in its presentation, so that we can thus establish the best strategy before the debate on the new perspectives.
because we should first define the content of policies before allocating the necessary means for their implementation, as has been the case with the community policies currently under review.

Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. President, Commissioners, dear colleagues, after four consecutive years of declining unemployment rates from 2004 to 2008, the current economic crisis has undone much of the progress made.
Unemployment rates in the European Union have seen a dramatic increase. For instance, in Portugal, we have unfortunately reached a record high unemployment rate of 11%.
Another negative phenomenon is youth unemployment in the European Union.
Europe is thus undergoing a period of transformation and is facing immense challenges.
The crisis annulled years of economic and social progress and exposed the fragilities of the economies of its member states and, consequently, of the European Union itself.
The 2020 strategy outlines the paths to follow.
The European Union must step up all its efforts to promote employment and social inclusion, as an integral part of its strategy to combat the economic and social crisis.
Thus, the proposed resolution on the future of the Social Fund, currently under discussion, is welcomed, as this fund plays a crucial role in achieving the goals of the 2020 Strategy.

In fact, this fund is the primary financial instrument that enables the European Union to achieve the strategic objectives of its employment policy, by enhancing the education and skill levels of its citizens.
The FSE should be strengthened as the main driver of the 2020 Strategy and should be used by Member States to invest in job qualification, training, and vocational retraining.

Finally, I would like to emphasize that the reform of the European Social Fund, when carried out in conjunction with the reform of the other structural funds, should facilitate and simplify their management.
enhance transparency, as well as focus funds on achieving results and realizing objectives that are genuinely felt by citizens in their daily lives. Thank you very much.
The European Social Fund is likely the most structuring instrument of cohesion.
should therefore have a strong articulation with the Regional Development Fund.
It is fundamental to take a local approach to the issues to be addressed, that is, a global perspective for local action.

Local and regional authorities are the entities most familiar with their realities, their investment needs for job creation, and what measures are most suitable for promoting employment in their regions.
We should take into account the positive experiences of the regions.
In the Azores, an ultra-peripheral region where unemployment typically reaches record levels, the unemployment rate is 6.5%, the lowest in Portugal.

This is due, to a large extent, to the forward-looking planning strategy employed for job creation, which defines the factors to act upon, how to achieve the desired flow, and also the use of the European Social Fund as an operational instrument of this strategy, acting on education, training, and employment promotion.
The horizontality of the cohesion policy is the only way to ensure the success of the Strategy.
The cohesion policy is the cornerstone of European solidarity.
It is through cohesion that the objective of reducing disparities between regions is achieved and the harmonious development of the entire European Union is encouraged.
In the upcoming period from 2014 to 2020, we must establish a framework that can enhance the effectiveness of regional policy.

Governance at various levels should be encouraged with greater involvement and participation of regional and local entities, respecting the principle of subsidiarity and as provided for in the new Treaty of Lisbon.
The special situation of the outermost regions must not be overlooked.
This group of regions faces significant challenges and should continue to benefit in the future from specific provisions in the implementation of European policies.
GDP should continue to be the primary eligibility criterion, but we should take into account other indicators that can provide a more comprehensive picture of the regional reality.
...aging and with very low birth rates.
These factors pose immense challenges for the European Union, to which we must provide concrete responses.
This observation has been consensual throughout our debate, despite the differing perspectives that this discussion has been bringing to light.
In Portugal, for example, the birth rate does not ensure generational renewal and reveals a reality that compromises the future.
This situation occurs in my country as it does in most member states of the European Union.
I am confident that more flexible policies regarding maternity leave can help reverse these trends.
We should send families a consistent message of support for motherhood, with concrete measures for better reconciliation of professional, private, and family life.
Women should be protected so that they can choose to have children without having to leave the labor market.
The achievement of this challenge is essential if we are to meet the economic and social objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy and combat demographic aging.
In Portugal, for example, maternity leave is already paid at 100% for 120 days, in an attempt to counteract the aforementioned decline in birth rates that we are experiencing.
I therefore argue that women's salaries should be guaranteed during maternity leave as outlined in the report under discussion.
Allowing each Member State, by 2020, to create the conditions that ensure the goal of full salary payment during maternity leave seems a prudent procedure.
Finally, I congratulate the rapporteur, Edith Estrela, for her persistence in advocating for measures aimed at protecting families, which also contribute to counteracting population decline.

Firstly, regarding these two reports, I would like to congratulate and publicly acknowledge, as I have already done in the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, the remarkable work accomplished by the authors.
colleagues Lena, Suoboda, Ror Berendt, Diana Wallis and Rebeca Harms, who were part of the Parliament's team of MEPs that negotiated this framework agreement with the Commission.

I would also like to record the great openness and highly constructive collaborative spirit of the President of the Commission, and subsequently, once the new Commission was sworn in, of Commissioner Shevchovitch and his teams.
I believe that a remarkable job has been achieved, leading to an historic agreement, one that represents the first framework agreement following the signing of the Treaty of
and the first framework agreement that has a direct basis, a basis expressly provided for in the treaties, more precisely in Article 295 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.
I wished to say that this agreement indeed creates a relationship of great transparency and dynamism, even a certain level of intimacy, in the connection between the
The Parliament and the Commission, and it essentially represents a compromise, a balance between the two institutions' visions of the new roles each should play following the Treaty of Lisbon.

I believe that the work of our negotiating team was indeed very positive, as it managed to translate into this framework agreement the new competences and the enhanced powers that result from the Treaty of Lisbon.
This holds true for the legislative procedure and for programming or planning, namely, for instance, just to give two examples, in the involvement of the Parliament in
work program of the Commission or, for example, on issues related to the use of soft law in areas that fall within the legislative competences of the Parliament by the Commission.

On a second point, a very important aspect is the strengthening of the Parliament's control and scrutiny powers. Whether it is in detailing and specifying the rules for the election of the President and the College of Commissioners, or, for example,

as regards the Parliament's presence in matters such as the reshuffle or the possible removal of a Commissioner, or, for example, the hearing of regulatory agency directors, as well as monitoring international negotiations.
In all these dimensions, there has indeed been a consolidation of powers, which are powers that stem from the Lisbon Treaty.
Also very important is access to information, and in particular, access to classified information or that which is classified information.
And, moreover, the very exchange of information and the sharing of perspectives between the Parliament's representatives and those of the Commission.

For example, we know that it is already possible for the Commissioner responsible for institutional affairs and the President of the Commission to participate in the relevant parts of the Conference of Presidents.

Or, for instance, that there are several dialogue platforms between the Conference of Presidents, the Conference of Committee Chairs, the President of the Parliament, the President of the Commission, and the College of Commissioners, all of them explicit.
Even the Commission's presence in Parliament has been strengthened, particularly through the application of Question Hour not only to the President of the Commission but also to the Commissioners.
I would therefore say, with profound respect for the Treaty of Lisbon and its new balance of powers, and with profound respect for the principle of separation of powers,
We have here a clarifying agreement that makes the Treaty of Lisbon current, that brings it to life, that makes it applicable.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, I begin by commending the rapporteur for her work, as well as acknowledging all those who collaborated with her on this report, which made it possible to reach this agreement at first reading.

The Chair's Directive, which revises the previous Directive dating back more than 10 years, aims, as everyone here has recognized, to put an end to a widespread problem in the European Union regarding payment clauses.
These delays, in some Member States, are unreasonably long when they involve the public administration.

The negative effects of this practice on economic life are enormous, both at the level of small and medium-sized enterprises and at the level of the internal market. These negative effects can no longer be tolerated, all the more so given that we are experiencing an economic and financial crisis like the one we are going through.
This legislative amendment provides coherence and meaning to the plan for relaunching the European economy and to the implementation of small business support.
business act. Surely, this directive will improve company liquidity.
Creditors will now have access to an effective and efficient instrument to enforce their rights against unreliable payers.
With this Directive, the reprehensible practice of public entities will become the exception.
Public administration bodies should set an example as upstanding citizens and pay invoices for goods and services within the month's deadline.
Now it will be up to the institutions involved, the Council, and the Member States to ensure that the transposition of this directive is carried out as soon as possible.
Thank you, Mr. Alves. Today, there is a significant disparity across many member states regarding payment conditions to businesses, especially when the state, SMEs, and large companies are involved.

We who come from the business world know that in this situation of economic crisis and increased financing difficulties, companies are increasingly facing liquidity problems and are indeed at an elevated risk of bankruptcy in many Member States.
It seems clear that the current Directive, which attempted to regulate this matter, had limited effects. Therefore, the proposal we are now examining represents an important step towards compliance.
the payment deadlines, not only in relations between companies and public entities, but also, and this is essential, in the relations that companies establish with each other.

We now have legislation that provides us with added value, with a clear system of sanctions for late payments, and which also effectively improves the balance in addressing the abuse of dominant positions held by the state and large companies.
Many thanks, Madam President. Madam Commissioner, allow me to address the unspoken.

I listened very attentively to the Commissioner, and from what I heard, it seems to me, I feel compelled to say, that up to this point, the most effective action, whether from national authorities or European authorities, appears to have been the management of silence.
Industrial accidents can and must be prevented. This is also the purpose of European legislation, and it seems obvious that the law has been violated.
There was ineffectiveness, a delayed response, abandonment of affected individuals, and particularly those most disadvantaged.
People have died, and many still today remain under the threat of what may happen to their health.
It is impossible to calculate the total costs, and it is immoral to neglect the victims.
How is it possible, I ask you, Commissioner, that we learn of news through accounts shared by Hungarian citizens, while the authorities see nothing or say nothing to us?
That is why I would like to raise a few questions.
How is it allowed for the Banking Sector to pressure citizens with mortgaged homes in the affected area, asking them to pay what they owe, given that their homes have lost value?
How is it permitted for phone operators to cut off the only means of contact for those in the disaster zone?
How is it that the company responsible for this catastrophe is already operating again?
And lastly, Madam Commissioner, you spoke about mitigating the effects of the blade spillage.
I ask you what the reasons are for continuing to mitigate the true scale of this human tragedy.
It's as if we're always starting from scratch.

Thank you, Mr. President. Dear colleagues, we all acknowledge that there has been a failure in controlling macroeconomic variables in the short and long term within the European Union, particularly in the context of budgetary frameworks and the accumulated national debt.
The crisis has underscored the need to strengthen the single market, taking into account the Monte and Greco proposals.

It is essential to develop electronic and cross-border trade, simplify online payment processes, standardize products and services, and harmonize tax instruments in order to build consumer trust and boost the economy.
The Union must emerge from the crisis in a sustainable manner, ensuring solid growth and responsible budgets, but also employment objectives.
Indicators such as the unemployment rate and the employment rate of the working-age population must be included in the monitoring system.
The indicators that will measure the progress of the 2020 Strategy cannot be overlooked either.
The feasibility study on the issuance of common European bonds could provide an opportunity to deepen and implement financial instruments for defense against speculation.
We wish we could have gone beyond a mere study.
The establishment of a European monetary fund deserves our support, and we view it not only as a discipline tool but primarily as a means to reduce speculative manipulation of sovereign debt markets.
Cooperation with the rapporteur was fruitful, and it was possible to achieve a comprehensive, balanced, and rich text.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. I would like to begin by thanking Mr. Feio for his reconciliation work and the spirit of compromise that he infused into his report.
But the conclusion we reached was that the Parliament, in certain dossiers, and this also happened in financial supervision,
capable of uniting and able to take a strong stance that defends the interests of citizens, and this strong stance must be recognized by the Commission and the Council.
This aspect is particularly relevant at a time when a legislative package of six extraordinarily sensitive proposals is being launched, and this Parliament has co-decision powers on many of them.
We will be equally active, but without concessions.
Our spirit is one of dialogue, but not of surpassing the goals we intend to uphold.
In this regard, the ugly report underscores some framing aspects.
One of them is that economic governance is more than a package of sanctions.
Growth and employment require dedicated initiatives.
There is a need for initiatives that address the growing internal divergences within the European Union.
Concrete proposals are needed regarding the European Monetary Fund.
stable, sustainable solutions are needed for sovereign debt.
We are at a juncture where trust hinges on the Commission and Council's ability to address the citizens' genuine aspirations, as well as governance, unemployment, growth, and cohesion.
I would like to thank Ms. BRS and all those who contributed to obtaining the report that is under discussion today.

Within the scope of this report and the Commission's work, I have drafted a thematic contribution that underscores the crucial role of small and medium-sized enterprises as a driving force for the recovery of the European Union and future growth and prosperity.
In fact, there are over 20 million small and medium-sized enterprises in the European Union.
Thus, if each one of them could create a job, it would mean a reduction equivalent to unemployment.
This document points to recommendations such as economic strategies for exiting the crisis, highlighting the main ones.
Firstly, there is a need to strengthen the social market economy, avoiding restrictions on competition and ensuring access to credit for small and medium-sized enterprises.
the provision of tax incentives and even subsidies to SMEs to maintain and create jobs.
the creation of a new Small Business Act with a stronger social dimension.
the establishment of a European network of reputable consultants for the dissemination of their knowledge.
Innovation as the most powerful engine of economic growth, and thus the essential need for an organic connection between industry and innovation.

The establishment of new partnerships between industries and academic institutions. And finally, the creation of an educational system tailored to the demands of the job market, as well as the need to develop new qualifications for emerging job roles.

and the Council to act, as they cannot do without an integrated European maritime policy in achieving smart growth, essential to the success of the Strategy 2020.

It draws particular attention to the biogenetic and mineral wealth potential that our deep sea and maritime bottoms enclose, which are still poorly understood today, and to the need to increase our research and development efforts in these areas.
Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to begin by congratulating Mr. Commissioner Barnier on the presentation of this important document.
Just as you diagnosed, the impact of the crisis we are living through is being felt in all sectors of society and our economy, causing our citizens despair and distrust of the single market.
But it is precisely this single market that is one of Europe's aces in the hole to combat the current crisis.
Therefore, we enthusiastically welcome this communication, which represents a new ambition for single market policies, allowing us to restore confidence in our social market economy model.
In the current situation, the European Union must pay particular attention to its 20 million small and medium-sized enterprises.
In this regard, one of the Union's priorities should be the development of mechanisms to address the issue of these companies' access to credit.

We also highlight the Commission's proposal to evaluate the Small Business Act by the end of 2010, with the aim of facilitating the lives of these companies, particularly through bureaucratic and tax simplification, as well as through the promotion of social responsibility.
We hope that these 50 measures now presented will contribute to deepening the internal market, making full use of its potential, which could represent additional growth for the European economy.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. We are here today to discuss what has been presented as one of the European Commission's top priorities: innovation policy.
finally takes shape, notably through European partnerships for innovation and with this pilot project we are discussing today on active and healthy aging.
However, there are still many aspects that need to be defined, particularly in terms of clarification, in defining future projects, and in establishing priorities.
Who, ultimately, will define the priorities and according to what criteria?
I believe these answers are owed to us.
But I would like to make a few specific notes, particularly regarding this first project on active and healthy aging, which was the one presented to us.

And these notes are, from the outset, a positive one because it seems positive to me that they focus on a sector of the population that is particularly vulnerable, in an increasingly aging Europe that is increasingly disadvantaged.
However, I would like to add further questions to these, as it seems contradictory to present a project in this field when at the same time we lack the means to support this innovation.
How are we going to sustain it?
What is the basis?

Is there any viable innovation in a context such as the one we are witnessing, where there is a persistent and systematic attack on the Social State, a reduction in access to healthcare, systematic cuts in the services provided, and continued disinvestment in this area?
The title of the presentation, a union of innovation, more jobs, improved lives, and a better society, is ambitious.

I would even say that I would have no problem subscribing to it personally, but let's agree that it is contradictory to what has been the practice in the Member States, with the cuts and austerity measures.

I believe that there is only sustainable innovation when there are rigorous, sustainable, and demanding public policies. If it is not a match that is extinguished, little remains and few answers do we have to offer these populations. Thank you very much.
Dear colleagues, we welcome the Commission's efforts to place research and innovation at the top of the political agenda.
We are faced with an integrated strategy to make the European innovation ecosystem more effective and productive in the service of a sustainable economy.
European partnerships for innovation emerge as an instrument and the broad challenges they address are extensive enough to avoid controversy.
However, it is still unclear how the sub-thematic priorities will be defined and how the preponderance of each discipline within them will be determined.
What level of transparency can be expected to engage stakeholders? How to arbitrate conflicting interests?
What is the relative role of the Commission of the Member States of the Regions?
How to ensure accountability within a structure that is complex,
What financial scale will these partnerships have?
The Commission and the Council, Mr. President, must ensure excellence in implementation, which is not guaranteed with the scant few months of pilot testing planned for the first partnership.

The International Trade Committee is currently examining the global agreement on bananas, reached within the World Trade Organization, and soon the plenary of this House will be called upon to express its opinion on the reduction of customs duties payable on the import of bananas from Latin American countries.

Let it be perfectly clear that none of the outermost regions, whether it be Madeira, where I come from, or any of the other eight, especially the Canaries, which are by far the most affected, are against the celebration of this type of agreement.
What these regions merely intend is that, on the one hand, the same phytosanitary conditions and respect for animal rights be demanded of others,
which are required of them to access the market, which is a matter of basic fairness, and, on the other hand, that they be compensated to the precise extent of the loss they incur.

Either way, if this is not the case, there should at least be the decency to openly tell them that they will have to change their lives and seek another occupation, because it is certain that under the conditions that are foreseen in the future, they will not be able to survive and will have to abandon the activity.
It is certain that in these agreements there are winners and losers. Let us then take care of the losers because the winners do not need it.
field. We are here to discuss a very ambitious program
concrete measures to aid economic recovery, and in this case, in a central area which is the energy sector.
In the current context of the crisis we are experiencing, it is crucial that there be proposals like this one that aid in the creation of jobs.
There is no possibility of economic reconversion if we do not prioritize precisely the creation of jobs.
This report sends a very positive signal by drawing our attention to how to respond at this level in the regional and local plans, concretely addressing local needs.
We are in a period where we are debating, and will continue to debate extensively, a set of legislative proposals in the energy sector, and often we tend to
We focus too much on what the major projects are, on what the large networks are, and we forget other scales of intervention where it is absolutely crucial to act.

And that is why I believe this report can help us to invest not only in energy efficiency and renewable energies, which is very important, but also to bring concrete benefits to local populations, which naturally translates into concrete benefits for the European population as a whole.

And that is why I would like to conclude, Mr. President, with two final points. It is important that we do not forget that energy efficiency is often achieved significantly through energy reduction in microeconomic projects as well.

microgeneration, as presented here, and the final note, which was a significant achievement of this Parliament in ensuring that there was a concrete definition of the funding amount to be applied to these projects.
This is not what we aspired to; we needed much more, and so I ask the Commissioner what he aims to do and intends to do to ensure these needs are met.
Dear President, dear colleagues, Commissioner Dali, the patient must have the right to know as much as possible about their illness and the available medications for treatment.
But how can we distinguish information from advertising?
Where and how to gather objective and unbiased information?
There are different interpretations of the texts in force. It is necessary to harmonize them, striving to reinforce the sovereignty of the citizen.
The information must be reliable, validated by authorities, independent, accessible, and targeted at a non-specialist general audience.
The aim is to foster a more informed and responsible citizenship among end-users.
The deadline given to the European Agency for tacit approval should be extended from 60 to 120 days.
The requirement for a basis of interference strengthens the contradictory and balances the final outcome.
The EMEA plays a crucial role as a privileged source of objective information.

I would like to conclude by commending Rapporteur Fielner for his work and expressing my satisfaction with the fact that he has incorporated almost all the proposals I presented in the Internal Market Committee as draftsperson of the opinion. Thank you.

Commissioner, dear colleagues, bee mortality is increasing and the number of beekeepers is decreasing. This is a problematic situation for agriculture and biodiversity, as has been mentioned here, given the enormous implications for food production and plant species that depend on their pollination.
The lifespan of a worker bee is very short, approximately six weeks, and it is highly sensitive to external changes.

Therefore, honey production has also been affected, not only by the increasingly uncertain duration and stability of the seasons, but also by the increase in external aggressions that may result from the use of pesticides, mites, or other factors.

nature and upon which the highest level of research could contribute to obtaining better applied responses and more accurate reinforcement of measures in favor of biodiversity and the reduction of the effects of climate instability.
The current programs, Commissioner, undoubtedly need to be strengthened within the framework of the new CAP so that we can also achieve a more effective level of response at this level.
President, let us be clear, the solidarity mechanism for sovereign debt has not worked and does not work. The price of Greek debt has not decreased, Ireland is still in a difficult situation,

The economic convulsions and contagion were not contained. The process that was established was created too late, is intergovernmental, and should have existed in a different format from the very beginning of the euro's creation.
The President of the Commission is now proposing to us a consolidation of this system.
But in the third of the instruments it proposes to use, it suggests involving the private sector.
We had already heard this proposal from Chancellor Merkel, and it was as a result of this premature and ill-timed announcement that the markets surged.
The Parliament will fully utilize its powers with the utmost responsibility and spirit of cooperation in the co-decision process accompanying the legislative package.
legislative action on economic governance, but it will not do so at the expense of haste and speed, relegating quality to second place.

Therefore, let us be clear, the Parliament will participate actively, but a matter as serious as the resolution of sovereign debt cannot be decided without and against the European citizens and their representatives. The two elements are intertwined.
Lastly, we Europeans need a clear European vision at this time of crisis.
A European mechanism for the consolidation of sovereign debt is necessary. Eurobonds must be issued, and the eurozone must be sustainably protected through European, not intergovernmental, systems.

It is necessary to reinforce the European budget. We cannot continue with 1% of the level of the European budget, and it is essential to place growth and real convergence at the heart of European political priorities.
It is this agenda that the Commission and the new President must uphold.
And the President of the Commission cannot be an emanation of the Ecofin Council.
This is what we need to present to European citizens.
Mr. President, Mr. President of the Council, Mr. President of the Commission, I would of course like to say that the EPP's position is clear. It is a position that advocates for...
that the resolution of this crisis, this severe crisis facing Europe and the European Union, can only be achieved through a deepening of economic governance and the communal method.

For us, there is no doubt that only with greater community method, only with economic governance, and only with the proper instruments of a single, genuine currency within the euro area, can this crisis be confronted and tackled.
But this means that each of the institutions, the Council, the Commission, and the Parliament, must assume their responsibilities before the Europeans.
And it must be said that it is clear here that, at least, the largest groups in the European Parliament are willing to cooperate visibly with a view to increasing.
the community method of introducing economic governance, of providing the single currency with the necessary conditions to succeed in the context of the European crisis.

It is also evident today that the same is true of the Commission and its President, who, contrary to what the Socialists and Member Elisa Ferreira claim, has demonstrated that he is neither an emanation of the Council nor an emanation of Parliament, but an emanation of European interest.
It remains for the Council, now in December, to assume its responsibilities.
It is on this that we rely, and on your clear adherence to the European ideal, President Wanderlund.
Many thanks, Mr. President. I would like to begin by congratulating colleagues Luan and Manescu on the remarkable work they have done in their respective reports.
both constitute an important contribution to the ongoing discussion on the new cohesion policy for the 2014-2020 horizon.
Today, more than ever, achieving economic, social, and territorial cohesion is essential for asserting the competitiveness of the European Union on a global scale.
This goal will only be achieved if we are aware that only by strengthening and developing the regional dimension can we have a cohesive Europe internally and competitive externally.

In this particular aspect, I would highlight three crucial points. Firstly, decentralization, ensuring that local and regional authorities, especially those with legislative powers, are more involved and contribute to the better implementation of the cohesion policy.

Member States should invite regional and local authorities to participate in negotiations on the future of structural funds, on an equal footing with national authorities and representatives. Lastly, the role of regional authorities should be strengthened in the preparation, management, and implementation of programs.
Only in this way, with the greatest involvement of these authorities throughout the entire process, will the principle of subsidiarity be fulfilled.

Another aspect I deem crucial is the request for a simpler architecture for post-2013 funds, not as a consequence of the economic crisis, but rather as a general principle of future cohesion policy, in order to facilitate the absorption of the funds.
The underlying major concern of the Treaty of Lisbon was to bring Europe closer to its citizens.
Let us not only do that, but also make your life easier by avoiding unnecessary administrative burdens that are deterrents to your participation.
Only in this way will we be able to achieve the goal of true territorial cohesion.
Only then will we see the disparities within the European Union reduced, which are currently stark and have a vast gap between rich and poor regions.
Greater participation also means greater responsibility. It is this responsibility that must be assumed and shared by all, doing more and better to have a stronger and more competitive Europe.
Madam President, Madam Commissioner, colleagues, I begin by congratulating my colleagues Edith Bauer and Anne Edd on the excellent work they have done on this report.
Human trafficking dishonors our society and demands a strong and coordinated response from all.
The organized crime that lies behind sexual exploitation, forced labor, the trade in human organ extraction, and other ignoble practices must be effectively combated, but primarily prevented.
What is at stake is the defense of human rights and the protection of the most vulnerable people, namely women and children.
The experience demonstrated that the legal framework in place was not sufficiently effective and that the European Union needs to commit further.
It is essential to have greater cross-border cooperation, including effective sharing of information and best practices.
In this proposal, a victim-centered approach is indeed emphasized.
Policies in this field should encompass aspects related to social affairs and social inclusion, such as the social rehabilitation of the victim. Thank you very much.
The NATO Summit took place in Lisbon, and therefore, allow me to say a few words about what happened in my country regarding this summit.
At that time, the Portuguese authorities prohibited the entry of European citizens into the country for a single reason. These citizens were carrying critical texts of the Alliance with them.
In these days, the least we can say is that an arbitrary regime prevailed in Portugal, an authentic thought police.
A regime so special that it prompted the Portuguese government to purchase riot control equipment worth 5 million euros, which did not even arrive in time for the summit.
And these are the priorities, after all, of a government facing a massive social crisis.
In the Europe we envision, freedom of expression is a fundamental value.
The Europe we envision does not bow down to military organizations that write their history in blood.
From the NATO summit emerged the legitimization of its military intervention across the globe.
It also emerged that the European Union was subordinated to the military strategy and interests of the United States.
In third place, the militarization of access to energy sources was consolidated.
Lastly, the military defense of the development model that generates environmental imbalances and exacerbates the social crisis was established.
By this, I mean, Madam President, that in my understanding, with this summit, we lose in democracy, we lose in freedom, and we lose so that some can profit from war.

And now I give the floor to Mr. Rangel, who has one and a half minutes. Thank you, Mr. President. The first point I would like to make clear here, and which is important to emphasize in this Parliament, is that...
that, contrary to what sometimes appears to be read in the press and in the statements of some European leaders, the euro, as a currency, has been fundamental in responding to the current crisis.

Without the euro, we would be in an extremely difficult situation, with the currencies of the weaker countries undergoing massive devaluation and a potential German mark appreciating to a level unsustainable for both the German and European economies.
And thus, the euro was a factor of stability, especially not only for the countries in the eurozone, but also for the currencies of those countries that chose not to join the eurozone.

And for that very reason, because we have to defend this community that was able to respond to the crisis like no other, and as we will see in the future, for example, what will happen to the dollar and the United States of America, we will see how the euro indeed has advantages...

We now have the responsibility within this Council to do everything to defend the Euro. Specifically, to create a stabilization fund that follows the community method and is able to introduce responsibility in the countries.

countries that are in a more vulnerable situation and solidarity with those that have fulfilled their obligations and that have not always shown, at least through their external statements, a willingness to be supportive in the context of the E-zone.

I would like to offer my sincere congratulations to colleague Sorbu for the excellence of the report produced, strongly advising that the Commission take it into account, especially in those aspects where the complex dimension of agricultural issues, which far exceed the strict scope of

agriculture, require the involvement of other areas, such as competition, the internal market, and financial regulation, as well as others. They also require treatment in other international forums, such as the G20 or the WTO.

The issues that are absolutely decisive for agriculture, for farmers, and for ensuring the availability of sufficient quantities and qualities of food for the populations of Europe and the world can only be effectively addressed if they are tackled in all their dimensions.

And the ambitious objectives of the CAP reform can only be achieved if the reform goes beyond the strict boundaries of agriculture and its objectives are also taken into account in the necessary interventions of other policy areas and in other global bodies.
This report made it abundantly clear, and I commend it for that.

Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, and dear colleagues. I would like to begin by expressing my gratitude for all the words spoken here regarding the report that Parliament presents on Alzheimer's disease and other dementias.
We all know that the situation we are facing is substantially dramatic and is still greatly underdiagnosed, as has been mentioned here.
And I would like to mention just one issue that was transversal to all interventions, but probably not so underlined, which is the issue of patients' dignity and their rights.
And not just from patients, but also from their families and those who care for them, whether formal or informal caregivers, and the professionals associated with this type of disease.

I am truly pleased, indeed delighted, with the Commissioner's words when he states that he shares the same concerns as the European Parliament and that the European Commission views all the recommendations in the report presented by Parliament very positively and will do everything in its power to implement them.
We know that each passing day is later than the previous one regarding the urgency of what we have at hand.
And therefore, we also know that tomorrow the Parliament will pronounce on this matter.
We will await the outcome of the vote, but we know, Commissioner, that European citizens expect much more from us than solidarity and moral support.

They expect concrete and appropriate actions from us. I hope, Commissioner, that you will then put this into practice, and that the Commission, which has the initiative—unfortunately, this Parliament does not—will put it into practice.

all this priority that you give to this domain and transform it into legislative initiative so that citizens and their families see their rights respected and are treated with the equality and dignity they deserve. Thank you very much.

Firstly, I would like to state that this Parliament, on a day when we are discussing the Hungarian presidency, without prejudice to addressing all the issues it intends to, should focus on the problems of the European Union, which it is not doing here.
And to focus on the issues of the European Union, you should read carefully and discuss here whether you agree or not with the priorities of the Hungarian presidency, instead of discussing points.
or aspects that are internal matters of Hungary and which, at most, can be regulated in a healthy and normal relationship between the European Commission and the Hungarian Parliament.

I would therefore like to say here that, in addition to the priority that the Hungarian Presidency will naturally give to the economic and financial issues on the agenda, I am very pleased that it is...
The Hungarian agenda for this semester is both lucid and ambitious, focusing and prioritizing three subjects that will be essential for Europe's future.

the food system, which is now facing a severe global crisis, the energy that is essential for our security and economic sustainability, and water, which has been little discussed but will be, after food, the next major challenge for Europeans.
I hope you achieve your goals.

Thank you, Madam President. I believe that these two countries, like others in the region, demonstrate how, in recent years, European leaders have often prioritized business over democracy, and dictators over the impoverished.
I am frankly concerned about the situation currently unfolding in Egypt and today's developments. It is for this reason that I believe we should not remain calm, but rather show solidarity.
solidarity with the millions of Egyptian citizens, both men and women, in Cairo and across the country, weary of hunger, weary of oppression, weary of unemployment.
And that is why, after today's speech by Mubarak, after the regime's dogs have been unleashed, after creating an open and clear path for violence, we must say that we have to stand by these people.
We cannot allow a strategy of fear to be created to make them return home.
Thirty-six years ago in Portugal, we would have returned home if we had heeded those advisories.
Fortunately, we returned because otherwise we would not have had a democratic revolution.
from the ECO.
either a mistake or a false promise, as you may call it, because we have been operating, especially in the collection of umbilical cord blood cells, based on misleading information.
And we know, as has already been mentioned, that in Europe the collection of stem cells through the umbilical cord does not reach 1%.

And yet, we also know that its possibilities for treating diseases may be inexhaustible. Diseases such as those already mentioned, cancer, Alzheimer's disease, and rare diseases, offer immense possibilities.

But what we allowed to happen was the establishment of a network of private cell preservation banks, telling parents that they could store their children's cells and, at the time of birth, potentially cure them in the future if needed.
I believe we should be more responsible than that because, as we know, the likelihood of ensuring it happens is very low.
And this false promise that is sold to parents comes at a cost.
In Portugal, for example, this false premise costs three and a half minimum wages.
The solution clearly lies in creating public banks of terminal cells. Because only with public banks can we ensure equal use, equal access.
and effective medical treatment and more research that is equal for all, and not just using mesenchymal cells as a commodity or a growing business that is only accessible to a few.
Therefore, I believe that solidarity, common sense, and impartial information are not, after all, things that can be classified as additional requirements.
We do not have the power to enforce, but we have the power to promote.
This falls within our scope of expertise. I believe we should do this in the name of equality. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President. Food prices have reached an all-time high and this is the 7th consecutive time they have increased.
And there are several factors that can explain this increase, the first of which is a short-term factor,
has to do with the coincidence of poor weather conditions in some countries, such as Russia and Argentina,
But there are two structuring factors, they are of a structuring nature, and that is why I am bringing up these two factors here.
The first factor relates to the shift of some food producers and consumers from being exporters to importers, as is the case with China.
And the second factor relates to the ability of some large multinationals to manipulate prices in their favor.
And the example of cereals is this very clear level. It is dominated by six large multinationals.
This situation thus places farmers in a state of great uncertainty regarding food product prices.
Europe must, therefore, resume doing what it stopped doing some time ago, namely, protecting its producers and consumers.
In a world where everyone turns to forms of protection and where multinationals manipulate the expressed, we cannot continue to be naive. Thank you very much.
I would like to congratulate my fellow rapporteur, Marisa Matias, and acknowledge all those who collaborated with her.
Regrettably, in recent years, we have witnessed a rise in the counterfeiting of medicines in Europe.
According to data from the European Union, one and a half million boxes of counterfeit medicines are sold annually through the legal supply chain.
This is a criminal activity that poses a serious threat to European patients and the European industry.
The objective of this Directive is to prevent the introduction of falsified medicines into the supply chain and, thereby, protect public health.

I would like to emphasize the following key points in the opinion I have drafted. The introduction of the definition of counterfeit medicine, with a clear focus on consumer protection, the implementation of secondary provisions,

ensuring the safety of prescription medicines, holding all actors in the distribution chain accountable, and finally, the imposition by Member States of effective sanctions to deter this criminal activity.
President, I obviously want to thank all the comments made by all the colleagues, both male and female.
I will not comment on each one individually; that is not the intention here.
I believe that if there were any doubts about what the word "commitment" means, it was made perfectly clear here what commitment entails.

We may not all have the perfect proposal, but what is far more important than knowing if it is perfect is realizing that we hold an instrument in our hands that will enable us to no longer postpone the protection of patient health.
And we have the obligation not to postpone its adaptation either, we have the obligation not to delay real action, and we can only do this collectively.
I must also say personally, and the Commissioner mentioned the issue of inspections, in my initial proposal I presented an amendment for mandatory inspections in third countries.
The commitment is precisely this, and yet, one gains in some things, but loses in others.
We were explained by the Commission that this would be impossible to obtain.
I would like to make one more note regarding this commitment.
I believe that we all see ourselves in the commitment, but I also think and am aware that we will all be demanding in order for it to be fulfilled, because otherwise it will not be effective.

In this commitment, safeguards are in place to enable us to monitor the process, assess, and systematically receive information that allows us to verify whether it is being implemented or not, properly or not, and whether changes need to be made.

I would therefore like to conclude by thanking the European Commission for its cooperation, and in particular the Spanish Presidency and the Belgian Presidency, with whom we have been working together over the past six months.
There are no perfect proposals, no perfect interventions, there are flaws, but I believe we have a strong and robust commitment to enable us to fight for and defend patient health.
And since my intervention is also full of shortcomings, I failed to thank colleagues Regina Bastos and Amália Sartori, from the partners of the other committees,
Many thanks also for your support.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, it is not worth repeating that the current moment is the most serious test of the euro's survival and, therefore, of Europe.
The Polimata report opens up constructive solutions, and that is why I also want to congratulate our colleague Pelas Ideias Clansa.

The gravity of the moment does not stem from the fact that the eurozone as a whole has an excessive external deficit or debt. Rather, it arises from the persistent and severe divergence of the economies that comprise it, under the impact of common policy.
And we lack instruments that enable convergence between these economies, that allow Europe to regain balance, that enable Europe to grow.
Let's be clear, the eurozone and the European Union cannot survive with the current level of integration and the diversity of the economies that make it up with a budget of 1% of collective wealth.
In practice, after the crisis, the only solution we were able to construct was the recipe of austerity. And it is the workers and businesses who are paying the price today.
the deficits generated by the speculative crisis in the financial sector, in the rescue of which 26% of the European Union's wealth was committed.
The financial transactions tax, with a very low rate, for example, 0.05% on transactions of high-risk, highly speculative products, it is true that they should be paid by their consumers.
But why should they not pay if ordinary citizens pay VAT on bread, on milk, and on the most basic products?
The tax burden must be redistributed to harm fewer workers and businesses and be shared more evenly across financial sectors, especially speculative ones.
And, Commissioner, I believe that it is not for the Commission at this moment to reject or evade the clear message that this Parliament is politically sending you.
The public consultation cannot exclude the analysis of the tax on financial transactions; on the contrary, it must be examined with the highest priority.
We know very well what happened with the A flu, and it should serve as a lesson for all of us.
And I don't know if you remember well how all this started, but the truth is that it began in one way and then the response was completely disproportionate to the scale of the problem.
That is why the report voted on here today is so important, because we must learn from what was done so that what was done is not repeated.
We have the right to know who made the decisions, how the entire story unfolded, and who determined that it should have happened this way.
as we have the right to know which countries responded in a certain way, why they responded without transparency and without allowing us to stay informed.

minimum doubt, because we have maintained all doubts as to whether or not there was a deal. We need to have the guarantee that no trace remains as to whether or not there was a deal related to this flu.
That is why I understand, Madam President, that all threats to public health must be addressed, but it is not indifferent how they are addressed or who pays for them.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. We are here discussing proposals on wages and proposals on the retirement age, and the least we can say about these proposals is that they are frankly unfair.
It is unfair to insist on recipes that have been proven time and again to be failed recipes.

What is happening in Ireland, Greece, Portugal, Spain, Italy, and who knows how many other countries, because this is an endless cadence, are different situations in each of these countries, but there are some things in common.
One of the things we have in common is an unprecedented transfer of value from labor to financial capital.
We cannot accept this.
The other thing we have in common is that those paying for this crisis are the workers, retirees, and pensioners, and also an entire generation of precarious workers.
There is no guarantee of any kind in the society we live in. That is why I would like to conclude by saying, Mr. President and Mr. Commissioner, we cannot continue to condemn people to poverty.
I sincerely hope...
Thank you, Mr. President. I begin by stating that I fully support what was said by my colleague.

The prevention of natural and man-made disasters is of immense importance and growing significance, and the European Commission systematically presents us with a number of procedural intentions and timelines.
But there is a very complicated problem, as already mentioned.

The Solidarity Fund is an instrument that typically responds to these situations, but it does so in a very, very lengthy timeframe, from nine months to a year, and this is after the disaster has occurred.

As has also been mentioned, and I reiterate and will continue to emphasize exhaustively for as long as necessary, there is the case of Madeira. A year ago, it suffered a massive catastrophe and has still not received any support.
And I ask this, and emphasize the question, isn't it time for the Commission to review the procedure of the fund itself and the financing model itself?
How can we maintain an exception fund to address situations that are increasingly chronic?
We do not know where it will happen, but we know that it will happen, and climate change is here to prove it.
Therefore, an exception can never respond to a situation of regularity. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, the concerns raised here regarding disaster prevention and response are highly sensitive and of utmost importance to our populations, which must not and cannot be postponed.

We are discussing very sensitive situations that affect people's safety and their property, which often stir emotions due to the loss of lives, destroyed families, and the devastation of entire working lives.

Yet, all our demonstrations are of little avail amidst the media-driven dramas that impress and sensitize us all, if we then fall asleep on the job of doing the work required to prevent, minimize, or better yet, assist in these situations.
Mr. Commissioner, the issue at hand, very well articulated by my colleagues,

It is an area where the European Union can best demonstrate its presence to its citizens, helping them in disaster prevention, especially when these occur, and standing by their side in the moments when they are most in need and most vulnerable.
I will gladly respond, although I did not intend to turn a debate in the European Parliament into a discussion on Portuguese politics.

In fact, if Deputy Edith Estrela wishes to debate Portuguese politics, there is a simple solution. We should have elections, candidates for the Portuguese Parliament, and the opportunity, as the opposition, to debate with the PSD government the policies it intends for Portugal.
I will only say this: we can no longer endure a government that has failed four times in the span of two years.
It is impossible, unsustainable, not credible to the markets, there are no more solutions with the socialist government.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues, I begin by congratulating colleague Schwab for his persistent negotiation, which led to this important agreement, and I also acknowledge all those who collaborated with him on this report.

We aim not only to guarantee a high level of protection for European consumers but also to ensure that European businesses, regardless of their size, can supply goods and services to consumers in the 27 member states without unnecessary legal barriers.

This new directive will put an end to the legislative fragmentation that has been hindering our companies' participation in the cross-border market and will provide a significant boost to the internal market.
I highlight the new provisions concerning the information to be provided to the consumer, requiring this information to be clear, intelligible, and provided in a timely manner.
It is also important that the burden of proof, regarding compliance with information requirements, shifts to the merchant.
As for contracts concluded at a distance, especially those completed by phone or over the internet, their rules should be defined, and consumers protected by simple and effective mechanisms.

We are confident that at the end of the institutional negotiations, the new directive will contribute to making the European Union more competitive and dynamic, as is imperative in a global economy. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Madam President, Mr. President of the Council, and Mr. President of the Commission. Firstly, I would naturally like to congratulate you on the outcomes of the Council of 24-25 March, particularly the consolidation of the semester.

European, but, more importantly, whether through the institutionalization of the European Stability Mechanism or the so-called Europlus Pact, which already emerged from the Eurozone Summit of March 11.
I believe these are very positive results for Europe, and it is only a pity that this process was not fully completed on March 24-25.
I believe that if we had given that signal, if the Member States had given that signal in the Council, by fully closing this fund reform package, we would be in a different position today.

stronger to face the three, four months ahead. And, in part, we would have mitigated the effects of the crisis that my country, Portugal, is currently experiencing, and about which I also want to say a few words.
To state that, in the case of the PSD, fully integrated within the EPP, there is an absolute and total willingness to meet the requirements and obligations of integration into the European area.
This is what we have been doing, even now, at this very moment, amidst difficulties regarding short-term financing.
Unlike what the Socialist Government has done, the Social Democrat Party has demonstrated full willingness to provide Europe with any guarantees necessary in the context of this crisis.

And with this, I want to give this signal, without bringing domestic politics into the European Parliament, of the commitment, the full guarantee of the Social Democratic Party in the rigorous agenda that the country will have to adopt after its elections on June 5th.
Thank you very much, Madam President, dear colleagues, Commissioner Stefan Fuller. The historic moment we are living demands firm and determined action.
Like many of you, we are watching the events unfolding in the Mediterranean Basin with a mix of hope, concern, and anticipation.

I nonetheless feel satisfied with the proactive stance that Parliament is set to adopt regarding the review of the European Union's Southern Neighborhood Policy, which I hope will lead to a greater presence of the Union in this region, not only as a payer, but also as a committed partner.
Firstly, by asserting the absolute necessity of upholding our founding values in relations with neighboring countries.
We can no longer compromise on the defense of democracy, nor on the defense of human rights, and even less on the defense of social justice.

We can no longer prioritize short-term stability at the expense of the higher interests of citizens and their unwavering defense, their individual and collective freedom, with particular attention to the rights of women.
In the future, the Union must prioritize a bottom-up approach in its neighborhood policy.
It is imperative that this happens.
Only the greater involvement of local communities and civil society will ensure maximum effectiveness in its implementation.

But I cannot help but express my frustration. I regret that this Parliament and the Commission do not wish to seize this opportunity to finally differentiate the Eastern Neighborhood Policy with countries that could potentially become our partners in the Union in the future from the Southern Neighborhood Policy.
I also challenge the Commission to demonstrate, in its review process of April 20th, the ambition that the current moment demands, a neighborhood policy.
custom-made to suit each state, with clearer goals and a careful assessment that can lead to a future Mediterranean economic space with the new democracies of the South.

To conclude, Commissioner, we trust that the positive atmosphere and cooperation that have characterized the work on this subject will lead to a permanent involvement of the European Parliament in the planning and evaluation of this policy. Thank you very much.
Many thanks, Mr. President. The reports we have debated, and I congratulate the rapporteurs on these, reinforce a series of initiatives aimed at revitalizing the internal market.
I would like to emphasize the commitment of the European Commission, in particular Commissioner Barnier, whom I welcome, and the positive reception of this Parliament through the
Consumer Protection and Internal Market Committee, to prioritize the competitiveness and dynamism of the market, a fundamental pillar of the Strategy 2020.
Citizens and businesses anticipate effective impulses for Europe's economic growth to resume, they expect an increase in employment, and they aspire to create greater prosperity.

And as the Commissioner emphasized, opening markets to our companies, by eliminating obstacles and difficulties, will provide a very special boost and a unique opportunity that will enable them to continue their mission as the driving force of our economy.

Measures aimed at reducing the administrative and bureaucratic burden on SMEs, and their access to credit and the services market, as well as the European patent and recognition of qualifications, are essential.
the relevance of developing e-commerce to strengthen consumer and business confidence in this type of trade, the focus on innovation.
Social entrepreneurship is crucial for robust and sustainable growth. It is indispensable in creating innovative business projects for social inclusion.
These are some measures that will ensure this ambitious project of completing, deepening, and making full use of the single market for the benefit of European citizens.
Finally, the important recommendation that Member States redouble their efforts to improve the transposition and implementation of internal market rules. Thank you very much.
I also wish to add my voice to those who have expressed concerns about the low earnings of fishermen, exacerbated by the historic high prices of fuels, especially in recent months.

As has been very rightly pointed out here, fuel costs have a very high impact on the survival of our small and medium-sized shipowners, exacerbating the already fragile revenues from fishing with particular severity.
This alarming rise in prices is also having profound negative effects on us. Reduced fishing trips, meager earnings for fishermen, exacerbated by the low prices paid at first sale,

increases in imports from third countries of aquaculture and fisheries products into the European market and a consequent abandonment of the activity due to financial difficulties, such as the loss of jobs.
In this context, to prevent the continuation of the deepening of the crisis, it is necessary to act and to act with solidarity and in-depth on the problems of fisheries.

The Commission must, therefore, provide positive responses with short- and long-term measures to address the adversities facing the sector and the severe income losses being experienced by our fishermen.
Firstly, I would like to congratulate, in particular, the work of our colleague from PPE, Mário David, whom I represent here today as he is fully informed.
unable to attend this plenary session, I would like to state that we have always considered supporting the victims of the floods in Pakistan to be an ethical and moral imperative.
And therefore, we strongly support all measures that have been taken towards traditional humanitarian aid.
We truly believe that efforts should continue to be made to help stabilize the situation of so many millions of people affected.
What we cannot accept is that the European Union's trade policy is now considered an appropriate and suitable instrument for humanitarian aid.

The truth is that this has two dire consequences. One within the European Union, particularly for the countries of the South and their textile-clothing industry, now highly vulnerable due to an unprecedented economic, social, and financial crisis since the

And secondly, at a global level, in the WTO negotiations, where this opening of the world's largest trading bloc, which is the European Union, to potential Pakistani exports could completely destabilize the WTO negotiations.
And it is not by chance that they find themselves in the impasse they are in.

It is, therefore, natural that, faced with such a situation, we must say, in light of the history of this Regulation and the difficulties it encountered during these eight months of intense negotiations, that

with which we collaborate with the most constructive proposals that, unfortunately, we now have to take a stance that will be a position to support the amendment that, in essence, provides for the end of this draft regulation as we know it.
We must do so at this moment, not out of lesser solidarity with Pakistan, but because we believe that humanitarian aid should be provided in the proper place and in the proper manner.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I would like to begin by saying that, of course, I believe the agreement reached for Portugal is a balanced one.
It is a very tough agreement for the populations, but it places its fundamental point on structural reforms to increase growth and competitiveness.
And I believe that this is very positive.

I do not adopt the stance of others who believe that countries like Greece, Ireland, and Portugal did everything right, made no mistakes, did not overreact, and did everything correctly, and that it was only the international crisis that caused problems.

No. Our governments have erred and pursued mistaken policies. However, this does not mean that there is not now an opportunity within the context of the Union to have the possibility of getting back on the right track and the correct path.
