And so it is important to recall here that, in fact, one must tell the public opinions that are against supporting countries in difficulty that they are not giving money to these countries, they are only lending money to them.
but they are lending them at very high interest rates and, therefore, they are making a deal that is positive for their budgets and for their populations.
But I also say here that perhaps it is time for a comprehensive European response with the introduction of eurobonds, and the possibility of primary market sales to address international markets.

And perhaps it is time for the European Commission, the Fund, and the IMF to review interest rates, in order to provide the possibility of, by lowering these rates, achieving sustained growth in these countries that are currently in difficulty.

Thank you. I give the floor to Mr. Correia de Campos for one minute. Thank you very much, Mr. President, Commissioner, and Rapporteur. This strategy is important for all European countries, especially those whose economies require greater competitiveness.
It is essential for the creation of small and medium-sized enterprises.
Today, there is more active generation of new jobs.
It is essential for universities and laboratories, whose relationship with productive sectors depends on part of their survival.
It is essential for the financial system to find a new market in innovation as the traditional manufacturing model exhausts itself.

Innovation is at the forefront of the European agenda and, as a pillar of the EU 2020 strategy, must be supported by new financial instruments to prevent it from succumbing to cyclical budgetary constraints.
Finally, I would like to acknowledge Judite Merckes for her significant contribution to a more innovative Europe with an economy more grounded in knowledge. Thank you very much.
President, Madam President, Madam Commissioner, I would like to begin by congratulating my colleague Odi on his excellent report.

The interim evaluation, although belated, allowed for the highlighting of critical aspects of the seventh program. Its excessive bureaucracy, industry disinterest, the number and complexity of new instruments, and the slow pace of disbursements,
There is also a greater risk of funds being redirected from the current framework program to large-scale programs with questionable added value.

but it also allowed for highlighting positive aspects, greater articulation and international cooperation among scientific groups in joint projects, some success stories, including the European Research Council, and a more balanced gender representation.
There are priorities that need to be developed. Firstly, simplification. Secondly, promoting scientific excellence, not in some countries, but across Europe. A greater connection between

framework program with innovation, featuring instruments targeted at small and medium-sized enterprises and entrepreneurship, of which the most successful is the Eurostar program, which should be expanded. Thank you, sir.

Madam President, Commissioner, I will address directly the proposal you have come here to present to Parliament today, and I will say with complete candor that I believe we have the right, some of us, to be disappointed with this proposal, because not only is it weak, but it also contains numerous gaps.
I believe this is a European issue, not a matter of states with nuclear industry and those without. It concerns all of Europe, and Europe desperately needs good news.
And I must sincerely tell you that one of these good news items is assuring citizens that we are taking care of their security.
Now, when these tests are conducted as the Commissioner has outlined, that is, a first phase carried out by the interested parties themselves, a second phase conducted by the Member States,

defend these stakeholders, and a third phase is carried out by peers who are genuinely interested. I wonder if the result won't end up being that all nuclear power plants are in excellent health and are highly recommended.

We know this is not the case, and for that reason, I sincerely hope there are serious consequences and that we can tell our citizens, both male and female, that we are taking care of their safety and not just pretending to. Thank you very much.
I expect from this European Council, especially given the climate of recent weeks, a decision of great responsibility.
And it is a matter of greater responsibility than that shown in the last Council, where an attempt was made to postpone a problem for three months solely due to electoral calendars.

I hope that this decision, fundamentally, will demonstrate that economic and financial matters are crucial and decisive for Europe, but that they are instrumental to what is the primary purpose of Europe—the goal of maintaining peace.
If there is an approach to the problems that leads solely to states beginning to distrust each other, to instigate distrust among the different states,
fostering and inflaming differences and rivalries between Southern and Northern states, between central and peripheral states. What we will be led to is the decline of the European Union.

I believe that what is at stake in this European Council, regardless of technical solutions, regardless of political disagreements, is whether we want the European project to remain a valid strategy for peace in Europe or not.
I swear, this is what is at stake.
What I notice in many speeches by leaders, both those from countries in distress and those from economically contributing countries,
contributors, it is an irresponsible discourse, which often even appeals to certain characteristics of nationalities that are extremely negative.
I appeal, and only for this, to the sense of responsibility of the leaders of the European governments to find solutions that lead Europe to an exit and a solution.

Many thanks, Madam President, Mr. Commissioner. My first words are to commend the work carried out by the rapporteur, colleague Jorge Sravacakis, who has done an extraordinary job in identifying future synergies for enhanced effectiveness among the various structural funds.

Your report also falls within this joint debate on cohesion policy, a debate of utmost importance, not only due to the substance of the topic but also, and primarily, because of the timing of its discussion.
Indeed, we are now in the process of becoming acquainted with the Commission's proposal, not only regarding the new financial perspectives but also concerning the future cohesion policy post-2013.
Cohesion policy is a fundamental policy for the European Union.

It is a horizontal policy that, through its instruments par excellence, the structural funds, finances projects and programs in the Member States, aiming to reduce the disparity between the levels of development of the various regions.
Experience, however, has shown us the difficulties in terms of efficiency and results that arise from the fragmentation and complexity of this policy.

I argue that a single strategic framework for the various funds, with an integrated and results-oriented approach, is the starting point for achieving greater and better synergies among the different instruments and for enhancing their effectiveness.
It is also essential for better coordination among various sectoral policies and for greater efficiency in resource allocation.
We must seize the danger of crisis to seek new alternatives.

It is certain that all these reports that are under discussion here today will present us with enormous challenges. And we know that to meet these challenges, we also need a good budget. But we must make a clear distinction between budgetary aspects and political objectives.
Political objectives are well-known. Indeed, it is only by asserting these political objectives that we can offer a future for the regions.
And if this is the case, we must then put the budget at the service of the future of the regions and citizens, and not the citizens and regions at the service of the budget. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President. Cohesion policy is the key policy for the future of the European project.
The construction of a common space, with an internal market and a single currency, requires a certain level of convergence among its member states and regions in order to function effectively.
The current competitiveness divergences, the development asymmetries, have inevitably led to the fragilization of the European space and the crisis affecting the eurozone.
That is why this vital need for convergence absolutely requires a strong cohesion budget, one that cannot be weakened to fund other policies.
The European Union, to do more, must have more. And this is achieved by growing its budget, not by reducing, even skillfully, the cohesion budget.

I therefore ask Commissioner whether the establishment of the Infrastructure Fund and the new innovation policies, which will be articulated with cohesion and regional development, which I support, without an increase in the Community budget, could become the Trojan horse introduced into the cohesion budget.
The modernization and renewal of energy infrastructure are essential factors for the sustainable and smart growth objectives we seek with the 2020 Strategy and for the energy security we require.
It is indispensable to engage all regions in this challenge.

To achieve this, the incentives provided for in regulatory systems should be enhanced, particularly those applicable to higher-risk and more innovative projects, such as those being developed in the Azores islands in the field of renewable energies.

Regions should be associated with the design and implementation phases of projects, in defining priorities, in their development and execution, as this ensures better results and thus a stronger defense of European interests.
The current economic climate further emphasizes the need to adopt an innovative and integrated approach to energy issues, taking into account all economic, environmental, and social aspects.
It is indispensable not to lose sight of its medium- and long-term effects, seeking to ensure all European citizens have access to secure, sustainable, and affordably priced energy.

The report we are debating is of particular importance given the influence that social services of general interest have on the daily lives of European citizens, as well as on social cohesion, job creation, and economic growth.

Collaboration with rapporteur Próncias de Roça was very fruitful and clarifying, as the rapporteur himself has just stated, enabling the adoption of several compromises in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs.
For the result we have here today and which we have debated, I congratulate and commend the rapporteur.
In fact, from our perspective, the main concern was to make it clear that competencies in this matter lie with the Member States.
National authorities are the holders of the powers to define, organize, and fund social services of general interest.
Thus, there is no need for the creation of harmonizing legislation at the European level, given the great diversity of these social services of general interest in the 27 Member States.

Simply consider the health, social security, employment, and social housing services, which are examples of how proximity and understanding of local contexts are fundamental to the proper and fair delivery of these services. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, as the rapporteur for the REGI opinion on the future of social services and international relations, I would like to congratulate my colleague from Roça by emphasizing the fact that we are dealing with an essential pillar of the social market economy model that we advocate for Europe, in which the SIG plays a crucial role in its cohesion.

Social cohesion at the European Union level recommends that the existence of minimum protection levels in all Member States should not be overlooked, without prejudice to the respect for the competences of their national, regional, and local authorities.

European regions play a crucial role in providing these services to their populations, and their perspective should be considered, given the unique nature of their constraints, to ensure the effective delivery of these services to the people.

In a time of crisis such as the one we are currently experiencing, the General Social and Intensive Service constitutes a social safety net for the most disadvantaged or for those whose incomes do not allow them access to private services.

It is, therefore, important to ensure that Member States that decentralize powers do so with the accompanying financial resources, so that regional and local authorities can guarantee their effective delivery to the population.
Lady Ashton, I begin by stating that it is obvious that we must continue to support the democratic revolutions taking place in these countries.
I don't have much time, so I just want to leave a few notes.
Firstly, we must not forget that the conditions for negotiation, with a view to a democratic transition and not civil war, have to be defined by the peoples of these countries.
The situation in Syria is grave. This applies to Syria, but it also applies to Yemen and Bahrain.

If we wish to avoid civil war, the last thing these countries need is for Europe to interfere in their internal affairs, and especially, and very particularly, through the presentation of military or paramilitary solutions.
And if I say this, I say it because we must totally repudiate what is happening in Libya.
NATO and the United Nations have exceeded all resolutions, including those voted on by the United Nations Security Council.
It is this silence regarding the relic, this repudiation that we must make, and it is because it is not included in this resolution that I cannot subscribe to it. Thank you very much.

Many thanks, Mr. President, Mr. President of the Commission, Mr. Prime Minister. Firstly, I would of course like to congratulate the Polish presidency on the ambitious program it has brought here and, in particular, to congratulate them on...

neighborhood policy, not only to the east but also on the southern border, where I believe we are currently facing a challenge that is perhaps more demanding than the one we have to the east, one that is more long-term and less short-term.

With that said, I would like to ask the Prime Minister and the Polish Presidency to pay particular attention to economic integration policies, economic governance, and the supervision of financial markets.
I believe that at this moment, no matter how ambitious our goals are in areas such as energy defense, food security, the environment, agriculture, and multiannual financial frameworks, if we do not

Unless we resolve the issue of the debt crisis in the European context in a clear and solid manner before the global markets, we will not have a Europe strong enough to face the challenges that the Polish presidency has set out to address.

And that is why I draw attention to the fact that it is fundamental to convince the remaining heads of state and government that it is necessary to give the European Union more economic integration, more economic governance.

Without this, what will happen is that we, instead of being the leaders or, at least, the representatives of our peoples, whether in the Council, or in Parliament, or in the Commission of European Interest, instead of fulfilling this role, we will be merely...
Mr. President, as Chairman of the MASHREC Delegation, I would like to make a brief comment on each of my four countries, in quotes, of course.
Beginning with Syria, and reiterating what some colleagues have also stated, it is regrettable that the international community appears, in the eyes of public opinion, to have a double standard.

It is necessary to call out, if need be, the countries on the Security Council, and I am obviously referring to Russia and China, as well as Brazil, but with the right to veto, which have prevented the international community from taking a more coherent position in line with the values we should share.
With regard to Egypt, there is an urgent need to raise awareness among Egyptian authorities about postponing the elections, as has already been done in Tunisia.
As for Lebanon, I believe it is necessary for this debate to send a very clear message to the new Lebanese government.
so that they are aware that they will be judged based on their actions in relation to the charges brought by the Special Tribunal for Lebanon.

Regarding Jordan, it serves as an example that a peaceful transition is possible, and perhaps there is only a need, at this stage, to raise awareness and encourage authorities to expedite the process of reforms.
In a debate of this nature, we must obviously not forget the peace process in the Middle East. And we must reiterate our hope that the meeting of the Quartet next Monday can
effectively be productive and reiterate that this House would certainly like to see much greater involvement by the European Union in the entire process.

I have no doubts that there will be a new round of negotiations before the United Nations General Assembly in September. However, I hope that this round of negotiations will be productive and conducted in good faith.
Thank you, Mr. President. I begin by congratulating the rapporteur and all those who contributed to achieving this work.
There is no doubt that this report constitutes and will continue to constitute a reference point regarding recommendations and robust, coordinated responses to the challenges of the crisis.
The only conclusion one can draw is that the crisis we are experiencing will only be overcome through the deepening of European integration.

In a time of severe financial, economic, and social difficulties, and painful austerity measures in some Member States, such as my country, Portugal, there is a temptation to seek refuge in a protectionist and nationalist attitude.
But that is a mistake.

The European response to the crisis requires a genuine European economic government pursuing sustainable growth, promoting job creation, and developing the social market economy. It should provide long-term solutions with defined objectives that Member States can identify with.
The crisis exit strategy needs to be financed with a sufficiently ambitious community budget.
To avert a new sovereign debt and euro crisis, closer coordination in fiscal policy matters is necessary, along with the establishment of a system for issuing public debt securities and euro-bonds.
I conclude by emphasizing that during this challenging period, it is also essential to maintain social protection levels, especially for the most vulnerable citizens. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, Presidency-in-Office, it is often said that crises help to strengthen Europe.
Historically, that has been the case, but today I am not so certain that this remains true.

The slow, improvised, reactive manner in which the Union is responding to the Greek crisis exacerbates the situation daily and spreads contagion and lack of confidence in the Union and its currency in an alarming way.
This despite the eurozone's problems stemming from obvious flaws in the construction of the single currency, which now center on its weakest links.

In order for the current crisis to result in the strengthening of the Union, a strategic vision is necessary, as there was in the past, which unfortunately neither the Commission nor the Council has been able to instill in the program and the European project.
This parliamentary report, however, provides us with this insight. More Europe, not less, is the solution.
The Parliament recalls that the market and the single currency create unbearable divergences between economies and that these must be counteracted by specific policies.
It recognizes that the functioning of the euro requires a reinforced European budget with own resources, requires a European debt issuance agency capable of protecting states from market speculation.

and provide them with credit at reasonable prices and terms. It also recognizes that the portability of diplomas and the transferability of workers between countries require mutual recognition of social rights and pensions.
The Parliament has united to send clear messages. Let us hope that the Commission and the Council heed them.

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, dear colleague and rapporteur, first of all, I would naturally like to congratulate and commend the rapporteur for considering this report extremely useful. It indeed allows us to take new steps in the field of mediation.
The report presents an overview, a range of solutions adopted by the various Member States in the implementation, in the application of
Directive 2008-52-EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 21 May 2008 on mediation in civil and commercial matters.
Well, we all know the advantages of mediation.
On the one hand, it is a judicial means of resolving conflicts, contributing to the decongestion of courts and the rationalization of the justice system, while also providing for...
simultaneously offering the parties the possibility of obtaining a friendly, faster, and less costly solution than the litigation in which they are engaged.

In other words, it is crucial to reaffirm the objective of Article 1 of the Directive when it calls for the adoption of measures to encourage the use of, and access to, alternative dispute resolution methods and, in particular, mediation.
Promoting access to and use of extrajudicial means of conflict resolution contributes to improving, simplifying, and making our justice system more accessible.

This is therefore a very important challenge for the European Union and for the establishment of the area of freedom, security, and justice; I would say, for the concept of the rule of law within the European Union.
And it is for this reason, in this context of crisis as well, that I deem it highly important, as the report states, to raise public awareness and engage stakeholders.
judiciary for this subject matter and call on the Commission and Commissioner to rapidly submit a legislative proposal on alternative dispute resolution.
Many thanks, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. I would also like to emphasize the fundamental importance of this report in terms of transparency in the European energy market.
And I merely wish to state that this is the central realm of cooperation in European terms, provided we preserve certain fundamental dimensions, among them preventing
ensure that liberalization does not result in higher energy prices for citizens, guarantee equal access, and exercise caution regarding sanctions, as several colleagues have already mentioned.
And precisely because this is a central area of European cooperation, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I cannot help but refer to it and question it, and ask you face to face, Mr. Commissioner,
I would like to give you the opportunity to explain, in light of the recent statements you made regarding Greece, Ireland, and Portugal, as these are also matters of European cooperation.
Symbolic measures such as flying the flags at half-mast, Commissioner, only serve to reinforce the shame felt by law-abiding citizens who strive for a better Europe.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Chief Commissioner of Covites, Ladies and Gentlemen of the Council, Polish Presidency. Firstly, I would like to clarify that I will be speaking here in a dual capacity. On the one hand, I am replacing the author of the opinion of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, and on the other, I am speaking as a representative of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice, and Home Affairs.

constitutional matters, my colleague Messer Schmidt, a Dane who is absent due to the ongoing election process in Denmark at this moment, and therefore I am representing him as a member from Africa, but also as a member of the Jury, serving as shadow rapporteur on the Jury for this report.
The first point I would like to make is that, in the crisis we are facing, the economic and financial crisis, the issue of smart regulation, of better legislation, is a central one.

There is no doubt that, in the so-called structural reforms that can drive the economic and financial recovery of the European area, the improvement at the level of legislation and regulation is also absolutely essential.

It is evident that a Europe which aims to be dynamic and competitive must have simple and accessible regulations for businesses and, of course, for citizens as well. Therefore, it must be tailored to their needs.
The truth is that, in this regard, it is essential today that, first and foremost, the program for reducing administrative burdens be achieved, and that every effort be made towards this end.

promoting consultations with market agents, representative associations of citizens and companies, and conducting an impact assessment of the legislation itself, is also extremely important, so that the

The decision-making process can essentially be based, let us say, precisely on the opinion of those who are the intended beneficiaries of the legislation, and this can be achieved without administrative burdens and with fewer economic and financial costs.

It is important to note that, for the Committee on Constitutional Affairs in particular, the concept of the principle of proportionality and subsidiarity is relevant, this idea that European intervention should be appropriate and not one that promotes the complexity of the legal system.

And therefore, in our view, we have paid special attention to the enhanced role that National Parliaments play in this dynamic, precisely due to the principle of proportionality and the principle of subsidiarity.

It is therefore essential that we now involve National Parliaments at the level of Smart Regulation and legislative improvement. Whether at the European level or the national level, both legislation and regulation must be addressed.

be more agile, more intelligent, more efficient. And, therefore, this is a good time to put into practice what we announce every day, which is a more competitive Europe and a more agile Europe through smarter regulation.
Mr. President, the number of homeless people, as well as those living below the poverty line, has continued to rise in recent years in several Member States.
The economic, financial, and social crisis, along with the rise in unemployment, have exacerbated this problem, as everyone has already diagnosed.
We also all agree that this phenomenon is a denial of important values of the European Union, respect for human dignity, and respect for fundamental rights.
In my country, for instance, which is subject to stringent austerity measures, the concept of homelessness, as per the National Plan, includes individuals who seek assistance to obtain a meal.
And the number of people seeking help with food has increased by more than 20% since 2008.
A more significant increase is noted among disadvantaged families and individuals whose living conditions have been altered by unemployment and also by banking indebtedness.
This is just one example that demonstrates the severity of this situation.
Last year, the European Parliament adopted a written declaration on a European Union strategy for the homeless.

With this statement, this Parliament drew attention to the need for the European Union to develop a strategy supported by national and regional strategies, with the long-term goal of ending situations where people sleep on the streets and the phenomenon of long-term homelessness.
National strategies should focus on preventive measures, but also on concrete actions to improve the quality of services provided to the homeless and the availability of affordable housing.
It is also evident that this European strategy must be compatible with the social housing policies of the Member States.
We took careful note of the Commissioner's words and recorded the point of view he expressed.
I conclude by urging the European Commission to give a strong impetus to coordinate the action of the Member States and regional authorities to tackle this social injustice.
We discussed the peace process in the Middle East. But is there some ongoing process that I have missed?
Unfortunately, no.

The European Union, in line with the majority of the international community, repeatedly affirms its support for the existence of two peoples and two states, sharing the space between the Jordan River and the Mediterranean, who have the right to aspire to live in peace and security.
But without dialogue between the parties, who find themselves in a growing spiral of hatred and misunderstandings that has been going on for 63 years, only extremism and frustration are fueled.

It is crucial that Europe and the Arab League become much more engaged in the pursuit of a negotiated solution for the borders, based on those existing in 1967, with adjustments that allow the majority of Jewish settlements to remain in Israel.

May the issue of Jerusalem, the holy city and future capital of both states, be clarified and mutually accepted as a symbol of peaceful coexistence between two peoples who are obligated to fulfill the prophecy of Isaiah that this is a land of milk and honey.

May all countries of the Union participate in resolving the issue of Palestinian refugees, and may the international community and, in particular, the Arab nation, contribute to the necessary financial compensation.

It is still absolutely essential that a military force under the aegis of the UN and with the participation, among others, of American and Islamic forces, be deployed as a guarantor of the maintenance of peace.
So let there be courage and political will.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, tourism requires a clear and coordinated European approach, with a keen eye on the potential and challenges that the different tourism models have to offer.
The tourist diversity that the European Union offers is so rich that it allows for exponential growth in this sector and in the European Union's own competitiveness.

A bet in this key sector, which accounts for 10% of GDP and approximately 12% of employment in the European Union, will enable not only the creation of European added value but also the addressing of the economic crisis we are currently facing.
It originates from a region ultra-peripheral to Madeira, where tourism is the main economic activity.

Therefore, the creation of a specific funding line for the sector within the 2014-2020 financial framework is indispensable for the cohesive and sustainable growth of tourism, which is essentially composed of small and medium-sized enterprises.

The realization of a genuine, sustainable, and diverse European tourism policy requires a concrete strategic plan, with a well-defined timeline, actions, and funding, capable of enhancing the visibility and quality of the tourism sector in the European Union.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. The absence of an ongoing peace process is jeopardizing fundamental rights and has led to the adoption of unilateral measures by both sides, which are not sustainable.

has in no way contributed to easing tensions in the region, and even less to the effective pursuit of a life for the two peoples who have the right to live harmoniously in peace, security, and with dignity.

It is time for the international community to say enough. It is time for Europe and the Arab League to drive the search for a lasting solution, with wisdom, presenting viable solutions, without delay and with definitive deadlines.
It is evident that the United States and Russia are no longer part of the solution.
Let us start with Jerusalem. Why not revive the initial idea of a corpus separatum administered by the UN, which would obviously serve as the capital of both states?
Borders. Let's start with those of 67.
Exchange plots of land when possible and coherent.
Ensure the defense of Israel, an obviously unavoidable issue for the Jewish people. For instance, by deploying blue helmets with American, European, and Islamic forces along the Jordan River.
Refugees, numbering around 4.8 million, have the right to their dignity. To a future connected to a land, preferably their own.

But they are not exclusively an Israeli problem, nor a Palestinian one. It is also ours. It is a problem for neighboring Arab countries, for the Arab community at large, but also for Europe and the rest of the international community.
Colonies must end their expansion, and this is non-negotiable.
The announcement made today is shameful and reflects hypocrisy and bad faith in a declaration of availability for immediate negotiations.

Above all, we want negotiations in good faith, committed to a deadline for their conclusion, after which the international community, to maintain its credibility, will have to adopt a different approach.

Thank you, Madam President. Madam Commissioner, the shameful situation in the refugee camps in Tunisia has already been mentioned here. We all share, and I very much share, what has been said by my colleagues who have just spoken.
I will not refer to this particular aspect, but rather to another, more overlooked situation: that of citizens who were welcomed into Tunisian families' homes.

And this is one of the situations that should shame us even more, because let's face it, Tunisia, in a time of crisis, was being solidar. Europe failed to show solidarity and was not in a process of transition towards democracy. It did not know how to be welcoming or how to receive.
I find it truly shameful that we can count in the hundreds the number of refugees received in Europe.
Many of these people, contrary to what has been said, no, they cannot return to their homes.
And there were children who were enrolled in public schools, which has implications at the infrastructure level, and implications for the reception capacity of these countries.
That is why, Madam Commissioner, I am very moved by the appeal you are making, and I say this sincerely, not ironically. But please, what about the Commission?
And in Europe,
What can it do?
How does Europe live so comfortably with this double standard?
We are so quick to repatriate and so slow to help, Commissioner.
It cannot continue like this.

Mr. President, I would naturally like to congratulate you on this supplement of hope that you have given to all European parliamentarians and, in particular, to the citizens of the European Union whom we represent here.

And, having said that, I would like to state that we now expect the Commission, together with the Council, to take a very, very determined action so that this sovereign debt crisis can be resolved in the short term.
We know it's a marathon, but immediate signals are needed.

And therefore, without prejudice to us all already beginning to think about a treaty amendment that provides the political translation for the entire project we have brought here today, without prejudice to that, something needs to be done immediately.

This set of measures, and perhaps an agreement, an agreement among States, what I have termed a sort of parasocial agreement that goes beyond treaties and can, from this moment onwards, set in motion all these ideas.
Congratulations on your courage and determination.
I believe we are on the right track and are leaving here today with renewed determination.
The crisis that the European Union is going through has had severe consequences in all member states, with thousands of workers affected by dismissals caused by globalization and the crisis.
We must affirm our solidarity with these workers who have lost their jobs and state that Europe should assist Member States in maintaining a high employment rate and combating unemployment.
rapid reintegration of workers into the labor market is a top priority.

An example of the usefulness of this fund is my country, Portugal, which has resorted to it four times, although we are aware that access to this fund could be improved, especially in the countries most affected by the crisis.

Thanks to the existence of this Globalization Adjustment Fund, it has been possible to support thousands of workers through vocational training measures, aiding in the creation of companies and providing incentives for recruitment.
This proposal is positive because it will enable Member States to request the intervention of this Fund to support workers made redundant as a direct result of the economic and financial crisis.

We support the extension of the deadline and understand that it should be the Member States most affected by the crisis that have greater and easier access to this Globalization and Crisis Support Fund.
Thank you, President. I congratulate the Polish Presidency and also Mr. Commissioner Ali Ren, just to say that I consider that...

Today, building upon and advancing the measures outlined in the State of the Union address, a significant and substantial step was taken towards resolving the issues stemming from the European Union's crisis.
Because the Commission has undertaken here its commitment to use its power of initiative and to work with the Council to resolve this crisis.
I believe this is an extremely important step and is the only way we have at this moment to resolve the eurozone crisis.
There is no possibility of resolving in the short term solely through an intergovernmental approach. Therefore, it is necessary for the States, the state governments,
commission the tools and the mandate to lead this resolution process, to put it into practice, execute and develop this roadmap that it has presented here.
But I do not want to fail to mention that this is not incompatible with our doing so simultaneously, with our developing at the same time our capacity to amend the treaties.
I am also convinced that in the medium term, the treaties need to be amended. However, even then, we must do so with the aim of strengthening the Commission, giving it more power and a greater role.

It is through the strengthening of the community method, now in the short term and later with a change in the treaties in the long term, that we will achieve greater integration and a solution for the 17 countries of the euro area and for the 27 countries of the European Union.

Many thanks, Mr. President. Dr. Durão Barroso came here today to announce that, as one of the measures, banks that do not meet capital requirements must submit plans to achieve them, and if they fail to present such plans, they should then suspend dividends and bonuses.
I could not but agree with this presentation made by Mr. President.
Just this week, we witnessed what happened with Banco Zéxia, and a few months ago, an administrator of this bank received a €600,000 award for their supposedly wonderful management, as we are aware.
But to be serious, Mr. President, the Commission has to leave the governments behind and present the full package. And the full package is what contains the essentials.
The essential point is that the money contributed should be matched by a credit policy that fosters growth.
The crucial point is that banks start paying taxes on their profits, which does not happen in many countries, notably in my country, Portugal.
In two years, to be precise, in three years, this is the second time we are being asked to save the banks with taxpayer money, with money from the unemployed.
banks that also save the economy, aiding job creation. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, Ms. High Representative, there are times when I think I need little and to take stock, and this seems to be one of those times for me.
And it seems to me that this is because we always follow the rhythm of events and the response from one event to another, and we lose sight of the perspective of the whole.

It is true that each case is a case in itself and each country we are discussing here is a specific instance, but, forgive me for saying, High Representative, it seems to me that it is difficult to scrutinize what criteria the European Union has employed to act upon each case.
I fear that we are often hostages to the interests of the countries of the European Union, on the part of some of these countries in the European Union and not all of them.
And that is why we so often use the expression "double standards" in this House, and we continue to use it.

Sometimes it is sanctions, sometimes it is not. Sometimes interference goes as far as the bomb, as was the case in Libya. Other times, there is complete silence, as was the case with the invasion of Bahrain by Saudi forces.

Saudi Arabia, and let me tell you, Madam Baroness, I have been carefully studying all the files, and I have yet to see a single statement from the European institutions condemning the invasion of Bahrain by Saudi Arabian military forces.

Death sentences, it is endless violence, it is doctors and nurses sentenced to up to 30 years in prison by a military court because they were allegedly against the regime and not assisting the wounded who needed them.
With regard to the dictatorial monarchy of Bahrain, the dictatorial regime of Yemen, and the regime of Saleh, we have had far more silence than action.

I am not, and never have been, in favor of interference. However, I fear that we may find ourselves in an uncomfortable position, one that is perceived from the outside, Mrs. Berenesa, where instead of fostering development and aspirations, we...

democratic and revolutionary movements of the peoples in Arab countries, instead of aiding the first Arab era, what we do is prevent it from extending, whether by excess or by deficiency, and I do not think we should bear this sin.
I hope that the awarding of the Nobel Prize to a Yamite activist can serve as a signal that our side is aligned with the peoples who are in revolution. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Madam President. Commissioner, this is a good report from colleague Casa.
First and foremost, one must ask why the VAT (Value Added Tax) in the European Union should be revised.
Firstly, there is a need to align it with the single market.
The more VAT rates and varieties there are, the less fluid the market will be.
An VAT reform favors e-commerce, focuses competition on the value and base price of goods and services, and not on tax differences.
Fights fraud and ensures much-needed trust, especially in cross-border transactions. Improves the economy of SMEs and reduces administrative burdens.
What other supporting measures are already underway in the single market that could be associated with the IVEI?
Firstly, a simple, clear, and transparent digital support mechanism, measure 7 of the single market.
Measure 5, concerning services, highlights the need to revise legislation on standardization and the implementation of the Security Directive.
Measure 9 aims to remove tax obstacles and explicitly revise the VAT system and VAT equalization in online and face-to-face trade, which we all experience when ordering books.
The pressures for VAT reform have two fundamental orders of reasons.
Firstly, the economic crisis.
More revenue is needed, including, in some countries, potentially reducing labor contributions to promote economic development, shifting this burden to VAT.

Secondly, the second major source of pressures is the aging population, demographic aging, and the trend towards shifting from indirect to direct taxation, due to the reduction in the tax base population.
It is necessary to rethink the balance between this direct and indirect taxation.
Finally, in these reforms, we have to reconcile subsidiarity with harmonization.
It is necessary to restrict the range of variation in the standard VAT rate, so that we can all better understand.
There is a need for greater transparency in defining the reduced VAT rate and its scope, along with a clear and widely disseminated list of reduced rates.
It is necessary to study exemption thresholds for SMEs, fully aware that each exemption brings with it a train of small or large-scale frauds.
Finally, to welcome the Commission's recent proposal to create a European VAT.
Thank you, Madam President. I would like to thank my colleague Rula for the excellent report she has prepared.

Certainly, the advantages of public procurement are well-known, but the obstacles are also evident. Conflicts of interest between European legislation and the objectives of Member States hinder competitiveness.
The dichotomy, the price quality, and the complexity of laws and procedures are evident.
It is crucial to examine existing best practices, particularly in Portugal, where electronic procurement has been successful and has streamlined public procurement processes.
An effective European public procurement represents a privileged means of controlling public deficit and fostering growth.
To achieve this, it should have a stable and predictable legal framework, less bureaucratic procedures to attract SMEs, and uphold social and environmental values.

That is why I express satisfaction with the intentions that Commissioner Barnier has presented to us here for the revision of public procurement, as one of the 12 priorities of the Single Market Act later this year. Thank you.
I would like to congratulate my colleague Rula and all those who collaborated with her.
Important in the realm of public contracts is the issue of public procurement and
Unfortunately, the targets set by the European Union, 50% of electronic procedure submissions by 2010, were missed, with average values barely reaching 5%.
Only a few countries, such as my own, Portugal, have succeeded in this area.

The advantages of electronic public procurement are highly evident and have been outlined above. It allows for the replacement of costly access processes with a simple consultation of the electronic platform, thereby reducing many costs for companies, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises.

small and medium-sized enterprises, online advertising, and the ease of receiving legal documents increase the number of suppliers, enhancing competition, and enabling better purchasing decisions, thus making the process of awarding public contracts more efficient.

Easier and more flexible, it simplifies access to European Union public contracts, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises, thus facilitating their participation in the public procurement market, which are important drivers of the economy.
In this regard, we welcome and encourage the European Commission's efforts to strengthen mechanisms to make electronic public procurement an increasingly widespread reality. Thank you very much.

We are living through decisive hours for the fate of Europe. And while the situation has swiftly evolved, in plain sight, from a Greek or Portuguese problem to a major European issue, the truth is that the inadequacy and delay of the proposed solutions have yielded no effectiveness in stemming the rapid deterioration of the situation.
The pursuit of solutions tailored to individual states at the expense of truly European solutions has enabled markets to continue speculating on sovereign debts and has imposed deadlines and rhythms.
It is absolutely impossible for some states to achieve their goals through measures of unimaginable brutality being imposed on individuals, businesses, and the public sector.

It is absolutely imperative to find a common solution, already identified for the risk of excessive European debts, which alleviates market pressure and speculation, and provides time for the essential adjustments to be made.
Without this, what we will have at the end are countries that will continue without the means to pay their creditors, destroyed economies, and a great deal of suffering.

To the shadow rapporteur colleagues, with whom I had a fruitful collaboration, and I also thank the rapporteurs from the partners of the four committees involved. These partners are a valuable contribution to this report.
We received 400 amendments and drafted 47 compromises, all of which were approved.
This demonstrates the importance and interest generated by the topic of new skills and jobs.
It is, after all, about preparing Europe's human resources, anticipating the needs of the labor market in the next decade.
The key strategy in drafting the report was to rephrase common ideas to avoid repetition and ensure the report's coherence.
I believe that this goal has been achieved.
We all know that the crisis currently affecting us has highlighted the fragilities of the European economic and social model, as well as undone much of the progress achieved in the past.
Since the first effects of the crisis began to be felt in labor markets in 2008, Europe has already lost more than 5 million jobs.
Today, there are nearly 23 million people without jobs.
Youth unemployment is even more alarming. The youth unemployment rate is close to 21%, representing more than double the overall unemployment rate.
On the other hand, in all Member States, unemployment rates vary according to qualification levels.
This means that people with higher qualifications find employment more easily.
We also know that in the near future, the demands in terms of skills, competencies, and qualifications will increase across all types and levels of professions.
In this context, Europe faces four challenges. Firstly, job creation. Secondly, the need to remain competitive.
Then, the sustainability of social security systems. And finally, the difficulty in finding individuals with the appropriate skills to fill job openings.
This report thus has a dual objective. Firstly, to emphasize the need to act swiftly to address skills gaps in Europe. The second objective is to better anticipate the labor market's skill needs.

To achieve this, several measures stand out. Firstly, to ensure the availability of a qualified workforce, it is necessary to improve basic skills, as well as competencies in science, innovation, information and communication technologies, and foreign languages.
As I have mentioned, skill requirements should be identified early on, with a minimum timeframe of 10 years.
Today, we understand the potential of a new sustainable economy, the green economy, and the need for investment in ecological qualifications.
Subsequently, there should be an increase in participation in lifelong learning and vocational retraining, as well as a reduction in school dropout rates.
Another important matter is the mutual recognition of diplomas and professional qualifications, and the urgency of moving forward with this recognition.
Fourthly, we draw attention to the connection that should exist between educational institutions and the needs of the labor market.
Internships should be of high quality and supervised by tutors to ensure they lead to employment opportunities and prevent any potential exploitation of interns.
Special emphasis is also placed on the role of social partners and social dialogue.
The report also proposes measures to promote demand and job creation.
We have a future ahead of us and we need to create jobs.
And small and medium-sized enterprises play a decisive role here in achieving this goal.

It is also necessary to strengthen the single market to facilitate the free movement of workers, hence the need for coordination of social security systems to ensure that workers' acquired rights are safeguarded, particularly the portability of pensions.

Lastly, the issue of labor market flexibility. To enhance the functioning of the labor market, the rules of flexicurity should be tailored to the socio-economic contexts of each Member State. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Madam President. I begin by thanking all the colleagues who contributed to this lively debate.
All colleagues had very useful interventions and contributed to a highly constructive discussion on an agenda that is ambitious at a time when we are facing a severe crisis.

In fact, this discussion is taking place on the eve of a European Council which will reveal whether there is political will to overcome the difficulties we are facing, and if there is a desire to do so.

policy for a deeper coordination among us in economic terms and whether there is indeed a harmonized and unified will to move forward with the ambition outlined in this agenda. In other words, to have

new jobs in the coming decade, jobs that will give hope to young people who are currently unemployed and to those who are completing their studies, hope in an inclusive labor market that meets their needs and

ambition for dignification through work, and who also have the opportunity to be in a state of perpetual dynamism to keep up with the challenges of a globalized economy, with a dynamic that has no parallel in recent generations.

Therefore, our ambition is truly to achieve job creation and economic growth, not only to address the needs of those who are unemployed as a result of the crisis, but also to accommodate those who are about to enter the labor market.

response to the major challenges ahead with the green economy, with health services, with transportation services, and with housing, which require from all of us a different perspective, an intelligent vision, and an inclusive view of the labor market.
Many thanks to all.

Marisa Matias. Thank you very much, Madam President. What we were told today in the Council's statement is that, for technical reasons, democracy would have to be sacrificed in the context of the European semester. But what we are discussing is a political issue. And the question I raise is whether political coordination can exist without democracy.
Where, ultimately, does the scrutiny of the European Parliament take place?
Where is the scrutiny by National Parliaments of their major budgetary choices?

But, if the issue were technical, as has been stated here, then we are talking about a variable technique. Because we know how the Council substantially eased the conditions of the four countries on the waiting list, namely France, Italy, Hungary, and Spain. It did not do the same for the countries under rescue programs.
Therefore, what model of intergovernmentalism is this that allows Germany to offer opinions on Portugal, but does not allow Portugal to offer opinions on Germany?
And, Sir, I kindly ask you to pay attention to this. No democratic legitimacy issue is resolved by asking deputies to consult information on the internet.
This is a problem of information collapse, not a problem of democratic exclusion. That is what we are discussing here. Thank you very much.

Thank you, Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues. Firstly, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr. Ardenne, on the quality and timeliness of this report, as well as Commissioner Andor on the initiatives announced.
Poverty is indeed a very serious problem that requires effective and swift action to stem the rise of this phenomenon, which currently affects more than 80 million Europeans.
The severe crisis we are already facing has exacerbated this situation and made the times we live in dramatic, as your Commissioner Andor stated.
The number of people unemployed continues to rise, and we all know that joblessness is a passport to poverty and social exclusion.
This scenario requires resources, determination, and considerable effort from the European Commission and the Member States.
If this does not happen, the goal of lifting 20 million European citizens out of poverty during this decade will not be achieved.
Therefore, I warmly welcome the initiative of the Platform Against Poverty, which is a very important instrument for ensuring social justice.
But no one doubts that the best antidotes to poverty and social exclusion are job creation and the promotion of economic growth.
President, access to the internet should today be considered a new fundamental right of citizens and not merely as a mere object of commerce, because this right
Essential things such as freedom of expression, access to and sharing of information, access to and sharing of culture and knowledge, as well as democratic and media pluralism, depend on it.

And that is why this access cannot be subject to speculative tariffs or contracts that restrict free choice and the possibility of easily changing suppliers, particularly in the world of mobile telecommunications, as we also know.
Active citizenship therefore requires that comprehensive and transparent information be provided.
The blocking of internet use is not exclusive to political regimes that fear their own people.
It can also happen that, as a result of economic choices, options are offered that provide privileges to police clients, resulting in less equal treatment for clients who are not as profitable.
It is for all these reasons that I support the Parliament in clearly siding with the neutrality of the internet and in defending its comprehensive nature.
Let's speak the truth.
We have been taking the medication for three years to get out of the crisis, and the situation is worsening day by day.
In place of healing, we have created two fatal vicious circles.
The first, between banks and states.
In Europe, it is now easier to discuss the bankruptcy of a state than that of a major bank, yet it is still expected that banks will finance states and that states will bail out their banks.
This spiral must be broken.
The Commission must proceed with European legislation that protects taxpayers from banking crises.
But it is also vital to protect debt from speculator attacks.

And for this, it is urgent, and already in the afternoon, to prepare the coordinated emissions of sovereign debt, whether called Eurobonds or Stability Bonds, and to guarantee them through robust community-based instruments, not intergovernmental.
In short, we also need to review the involvement of the European Central Bank.
But the second vicious circle arises from the argument that some states are rich because they are virtuous, while others are poor because they have sinned.
This narrative is politically explosive and technically incorrect.

She ignores the essential fact that a single market and currency, constructed by political choice among unequals, necessarily exacerbates competitiveness imbalances between the center and the periphery.
And this is what needs to be anchored in economic governance.
No, Mr. Rompói, through sanctions that promote the suppression of wages and incomes via one country's control over another.
previously through a commitment, Mr. Commissioner, from countries with surpluses as well as those with deficits, in order to converge productivity through investment, education, and science.
The sanctions have only generated unemployment, disillusionment, and a wave of queuing from which we cannot escape.

Many thanks, Madam President. Madam Commissioner, the integrated maritime policy promotes a coordinated approach to the management and governance of oceans, seas, and coasts, from a global and coherent perspective of all European marine-related policies.

Having a global perspective and an integrated approach entails the interaction of European maritime-related policies and calls for improved governance through greater involvement in the European decision-making process.
The success and relevance of this policy have been demonstrated over the past few years through the various funded initiatives in the form of preparatory actions and pilot projects.
The integrated maritime policy should, therefore, continue to benefit from adequate funding during the coming years of the current financial programming period.
In this regard, I advocate adequate funding until 2013, not only to consolidate previous projects, but also to support the establishment of a stable framework for the objectives of this program.
Policy, governance, sustainability, and maritime surveillance issues are, for obvious reasons, matters of particular interest to certain regions of the European Union, such as the outermost regions.

The eruption regions, with the exception of French Guiana, are small and remote, relying on a limited number of economic activities, with those related to the sea and fishing being of particular importance.
Moreover, the outermost regions contribute to the European Union having the largest exclusive economic zone in the world.

The Outermost Regions (ORs) account for over half of the European Union's exclusive economic zone, approximately 15 out of 25 million square kilometers. Together with coastal regions, they are crucial for the economic growth of the European Union and its Member States.
A program like the one outlined in the Integrated Maritime Policy should benefit these regions, emphasizing the transnational coordination of maritime policies and relevant international cooperation.
It is therefore necessary to ensure continuous and sufficient funding, not only for the next two years, but also and especially for the next financial framework starting in 2014.
Failing to take advantage of the opportunity, when discussing integrated maritime policy, to emphasize the immense potential that the Atlantic and insular dimensions hold for the European Union.

The Atlantic, as Europe's western maritime border, also connects it to North and South America and Africa, providing a strategic dimension for Europe that is essential in shaping a maritime policy with a forward-looking perspective.

It is with a view to the future that the integrated maritime policy, in addition to promoting the coordination of maritime activities, must place at the forefront of its priorities the potential of the Atlantic in its three-dimensional dimension, based on science and technology.

The exploration of the Mid-Atlantic Ridge, deep sea, and marine sediments represents a new frontier with vast potential in biotechnology and mineral resources, holding incalculable value for the knowledge economy.
The Union should therefore take advantage of the Azores' privileged position and the excellence of its oceanographic department to establish a deep-sea observatory there. Thank you.
Enough of this path.
When the diagnosis is incorrect, the remedies do not work.
And in the case of the eurozone, the excessive remedies have brought it to the brink of death.
The successive miracle solutions that were proposed were equally discredited by the markets.
the Financial Stabilization Fund, the successive tightening measures of the Stability and Growth Pact, the Troika's revenues in the low-program countries.
Blind austerity without growth sparked a recessionary wave among fully interconnected economies, which thus became contaminated by bankruptcies and unemployment.
And into the hands of the markets, that is, the rating agencies and speculators, governments are falling one after another, and solvent countries are becoming insolvent.

Amending the treaties now is yet another step on this disastrous path, with an additional complication. We risk destroying what remains of national sovereignty, placing countries under the control of the European Court of Justice.
No, it is not necessary to amend the treaties.
In this emergency we find ourselves in, two decisions must be made.
Firstly, it is necessary to materialize a genuine agenda for growth and sustained cohesion.
Where is the Agenda 2020?
Where is the stimulus budget?
Where are the much-vaunted project bonds for Europe's structural investments?
And secondly, it is necessary to protect sovereign debt.

Of course, aerobridges are necessary, but in the emergency situation we find ourselves in, it is urgent that the European Central Bank, directly or indirectly, defends sovereign debt against speculators.
Not in a shy manner, but with a definitive, decided stance, as befits any central bank that defends its currency and the economy that sustains it.
For this, it is not necessary to change the treaties; what is needed is political will and European conviction.
Let us revise the treaty once we have drawn all the lessons from the current crisis. And there are certainly many lessons to be learned, but this is not the time for that. Thank you very much.
Mr. President and Mr. Commissioner Dali, the first Single Market Forum, an idea stemming from the Greco report, took place in Kraków.
was rich in content and fruitful in the debate conducted by the Polish presidency with European, national, regional, and local authorities and civil society.
We have a roadmap outlined in the Commission's communication of April 12 with the 12 levers.
The law needs to be enacted, along with the strategy for the other 38 priorities identified in the Single Market Act.
For a market to exist, trust is necessary.
Now, the trust of citizens and consumers cannot be taken for granted; it needs to be stimulated and nurtured.

The single market is not merely a buying and selling operation. It encompasses horizontal policies, such as health, social and consumer protection, labor law, the environment, and sustainable development.
The Single Market Forum should, therefore, become a flagship event of the European Union, held annually and attracting a diverse and increasingly engaged audience.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. I believe we are at a time for taking stock of these crisis policies, austerity measures that have affected so many countries, as well as the so-called structural reforms.
And it is in this context that I believe we cannot fail to see how they have caused such social upheaval.
And it has generated social unrest not only in countries facing the greatest difficulties, in the countries of the south, not just in so-called hotspots, but also in other European contexts.
Just last week, Portugal saw the largest general strike ever, encompassing both the public and private sectors. It was a strike that took to the streets.

But if we look at what happened today in the United Kingdom, we find that we have witnessed the largest strike ever, especially considering that people also took to the streets there, as they did in Portugal.
And we expect a large demonstration in Brussels on Friday.

What this proves, Mr. President, and what the strikes prove in people taking to the streets, is that the causes and problems we have been facing are common, and that is why the reaction is also common.
The crisis of the European Union is infecting all member states, reaching unbelievable proportions.

We are witnessing chaos in financial markets and the growing inability to secure essential financing for the operations of our small and medium-sized enterprises, even those that are otherwise healthy, driving them to despair, bankruptcy, and unemployment.
It is a spiral that fuels the recession and is destroying the economy and society.

No one denies the need for rigorous budget discipline, deep restructurings, and enhanced economic governance. But these are necessary conditions that, in the short term, are no longer sufficient to counteract the ongoing degradation in the Union.

And if the truth is that we need precise policies to stimulate employment and growth, without which we will never be able to control sovereign debts, the central issue today is to ensure the financing of our companies and our economies, without which the Union will precipitate itself.
Therefore, now more than ever, more than a revision of the treaties, we need a strong and confident intervention from the European Central Bank.
Thank you very much, Madam President, Commissioner. We are all gathered here today, united around a resolution with a set of very important requests in terms of intervention.
We are speaking on World AIDS Day, and this assessment of the 2009 resolution and communication is crucial.
It is fundamental, precisely, things that have already been mentioned.
We repeat ourselves because, unfortunately, there is still room for repetition, which means there is much to be done.
There are many new cases diagnosed every year in Europe and the European Economic Area. A 2010 report speaks of over 25,000 new cases.
If we consider neighboring countries, we are talking about more than 100,000 new cases.
And if we think there are things that cannot get worse, they can always get worse.

And one of the issues I want to make very clear here has to do with the disinvestment that has been made in the health sector as a result of the economic and financial crisis we are currently experiencing.
And this disinvestment has had a very serious impact on areas that are fundamental to the fight against HIV-AIDS.
It is for this reason, Commissioner, that I believe the Commission has a crucial role to play in urging Member States to fulfill their obligations in these areas.

A second issue also pertains to the rise in discrimination, further evidenced by the economic and social crisis. This includes discrimination against workers who have lost their jobs due to being carriers of this virus.
And that is why prevention, treatment, and care should be equal for all, regardless of gender, age, or the region where they live.
I hope we can implement these measures with the support of the Commissioner.
Welcome to this Parliament, Mr. Draghi.
We are facing exceptional and dramatic circumstances, which demand decisive and urgent action.

The spiral between sovereign debt and bank debt must be broken, but at this moment the priority is to defend the states, to ensure that the countries of the eurozone and the euro itself are not destroyed by rating agencies and speculators.
In the report we will approve, Tremosa and Bacel, we have proposals to rethink the architecture of the euro area, create eurobonds and a European treasury. But all of this takes time.
At this moment, we are facing an emergency, and in this context, the sole solution lies in the hands of the European Central Bank.
Technically, the European Central Bank knows what needs to be done.
Today, you should not be inhibited in your intervention and action by limited interpretations of your mandate.
Your mandate is to safeguard the euro, not to manage inflation.
At a time like this, there is no doubt. Saving the euro and doing what is necessary is what this Parliament and citizens expect from the European Central Bank.
Good luck and courage, Mr. Tragui.
The European Neighborhood Policy already explicitly included the positions that the European Parliament has been taking.

And it was with great satisfaction that we saw a large part of the principles and proposals that we have been advocating in this House incorporated into the subsequent communications of the Commission and the Council.

I would like to express my gratitude, in fact, for the excellent and ongoing collaboration and coordination we have maintained throughout this time with Vice-President Cathy Ashton and Commissioner Stefan Fule, as well as their offices.
first and foremost, through the upgrade achieved in our relationship with neighboring peoples.

By prioritizing relations with the general population and civil society organizations in particular, we will be giving greater objectivity and effectiveness to our neighborhood policy, which is intended to be exclusively based on the universal values that we uphold and share.
I emphasize, however, that the European Union does not intend to impose a pre-defined model or formula for political reforms in third countries.
But when it comes to our taxpayers' money, we should give more to those who are doing more to align with the values we believe in.
This principle signifies that the faster a country progresses with its internal reforms, the more support it will receive from the European Union.
The principle of more for more is therefore correct, fair, and consistent.
What this obviously means is that we also anticipate the hypothesis that there may be cases or countries where we will have less for less.
The neighborhood policy now revolves around upholding shared values and a commitment to democracy, human rights, the rule of law, and good governance.
But this search implies greater accountability.

Our partners are called upon to take on more responsibility in the process. Therefore, we advocate for the principles of greater differentiation, increased conditionality, and the concept of more for more.

By adopting a bottom-up approach towards our partners and tailored policies, what we refer to as a bottom-up approach and custom-made policies, we enhance the effectiveness of development and institutional capacity.

The institutional building that we so fervently wish to defend, which lies at the foundation of the rule of law and democratic process, and which we hope to see implemented as swiftly as possible in the societies, economies, and communities of our neighbors.

The idea is to give a voice to citizens, as well as to all civil society movements that align with our values, by supporting organized movements striving for positive and democratic change in their countries.
countries, enhancing the rights of women and children, building and deepening the principles of freedom, be it of expression, association, religious belief, press, choice, etc.
etc. With fair elections, the fight against corruption, the rule of law, greater social justice, respect for minorities, environmental protection, and resource efficiency.
The severe economic and social problems facing our neighbors also require immediate action.
It is evident that without our concrete help, the ongoing democratic processes may fail.
These were the ideas we have always advocated for the future European neighborhood policy.
These are the proposals contained in the report we are bringing to your vote.
It's time to act now.
For our part, we will remain vigilant and exercise the new monitoring and oversight powers now vested in the European Parliament.
In conclusion, I would like to thank my colleague, co-rapporteur, and friend Marek Sivic. I express my special recognition for his remarkable work on the eastern dimension of the neighborhood policy.
Also to the Shadow and Opinion rapporteurs, and to all of you for the immense suggestions proposed in the amendments you presented, which I consider to have enriched our work.
And a final word to the Secretariat of the Commission and to the Political Counselors for the excellent support work I benefited from.
In European neighborhood policy, excluding the ultra-peripheral regions, as active frontiers of Europe in different parts of the world.
As ultra-peripheral regions, acting as external borders, convey our values of democracy, peace, and respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms to third countries in these regions.
Regions like the French ultrapolymeric ones have an absolute need for greater integration within their geographical areas.
Remote from the EU's internal market, this integration is crucial for their development and represents a vast potential for deepening the neighborhood policy with neighboring countries.

The neighborhood policy requires a new impetus. An impetus that also leverages the privileged historical-cultural relations that the ultra-peripheral regions of the Azores, Madeira, and the Canary Islands maintain with North America and South America.
A more active role in support of the European Union can and should be played by these regions within the framework of a new European policy of resurgence.

Thank you, Mr. President. It was last September that, after in-depth debate, in which I also engaged as the responsible person for this matter within the Socialist Group, I promoted meetings and debates with European, national, and regional organizations connected to...

For retailers, manufacturers, and farmers, the Parliament approved the Bouvê report, which includes an exhaustive set of recommendations to the European Commission aimed at ensuring fair income for farmers and improving the functioning of the food supply chain.

Since 2008, in fact, the Commission and the Parliament have been producing communications, reports, recommendations, and establishing high-level forums and groups to address this serious issue, yet beyond raising awareness, nothing has changed in practice.

We return to the subject, and it is necessary to state it without hesitation. A significant portion of the problems faced by farmers stem from highly penalizing behaviors, imposed primarily by operators in modern distribution.
The problems are more than identified.
What has been lacking in the Commission and among the Member States is an effective political will to implement the solutions.
Until then, we will continue to see losses for farmers and consumers.
to say that this treaty is useless.
Unfortunately, he is above all dangerous.
Firstly, it reinforces a failed recipe with more punishments and strict rules.
The recursive spiral is unleashed.
Who can trust a doctor who cannot distinguish between weight loss and anorexia?
A doctor who, the more the patient weakens, the more he insists on the medicine, while openly discussing the likelihood of their death.
How many more countries need to fall into recession before the Commission and the Council realize that the diagnosis is incorrect?
But it is also dangerous, because we here represent the citizens of Europe.
23 million and 700 thousand are unemployed.
Nearly 6 million young people have no hope of finding employment.
Will the Council and the Commission not realize that ignoring this fact, failing to provide an adequate response, reveals an autism and insensitivity that are politically explosive?
Let's be clear.
The great recession is not a fate, it is an ideological obsession.
There is an alternative agenda. However, it must not be one of words, but of action.
Where are the project bonds to finance European investment?
where is the reinforcement of the European Budget with the tax on speculative financial products.
Where is the barrier that should protect countries from the ruinous interest rates imposed by the markets, leading them to ruin.
Citizens demand actions, not words, but competent actions. Thank you very much.
Many thanks, Madam President. The Commission and governments now promise to reprogramme structural funds to support SMEs and create jobs.

However, it is worth recalling that at the end of last year, the Commission also decided on the suspension of the allocation of structural funds to countries that do not meet or have not met the deficit or debt targets.
It doesn't take much genius to realize that either the promise is fulfilled or the punishment is carried out. But both at the same time is not possible.
And that is why, Commissioner, I would like to ask you a very direct question. Has the decision to suspend the allocation of structural funds been maintained? Has it been frozen or annulled?
In other words, can Greece, Portugal, Ireland, or other countries still access funds they are entitled to if they do not meet the objectives being imposed by the Commission and by you?
Respond, Commissioner, please. The thing is, in Portugal, we are very tired of promises, you see?
Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. Commissioner, the proposal made by President Barroso to reallocate available structural funds to support our SMEs.
and stimulating employment, especially youth employment, could not be more welcome, especially for economies subject to harsh austerity measures, such as the Portuguese economy.

With the agreement on external intervention and the significant financing difficulties faced by the economy, and particularly our small and medium-sized enterprises, through the banking system, this proposal takes on special importance for regions such as the Azores. These regions, despite their high absorption and good use of funds, are embedded within a recessionary context.
